Peking duck wraps & Big Erns tuna poke are a must!  Fun to watch the large shared island drinks being served over dry ice as the vapor pours over the entire table...spooky...

Stop by this dark and exciting island departure and you will have a blast!  If you want a table...book weeks in advance.
Food is not very good, but drinks are extravagant, love the vibes from this place. A great spot for a girls night!

Came here for my birthday and had a great time. Make sure to get reservations for a table so you don't have to crowd around the bar. Drinks come in pretty mug/cup. Entrance takes you downstairs pass a bunch of blue lite skulls wall, when you get inside it's tiki theme.

Good vibe!

pics.caption: When you want a sample of everything...

review.des: My boyfriend and I visited Three Dots and a Dash on September 29th and was blown away by how amazing this tiki bar is! We, especially myself, LOVED EVERYTHING ABOUT IT! The ambiance was cool, tiki inspired decor around the whole place. The drinks were perfectly made, great balanced drinks utilizing fresh ingredients and great technique. It was visually appealing to watch the bartender Danny mix drinks with a smile while being able to maintain a conversation. Danny, you are awesome and your hospitality that night was very much appreciated! Everyone was so friendly and the place was definitely welcoming all around. We only shared one appetizer which was the short ribs on rice. It was good but the portion was small for $14. Other than that, this place is a must go if you are visiting! You'll be in awe like we were! :)

pics.caption: Can't remember the names of the drink, but they were superb!

review.des: This place is AWESOME!!!!!! We ordered the Bali Bali drink that came to us with dry ice in a beautiful set up. The drink tasted phenomenal. The food was delicious as well. We ordered the platter and it was perfect. This is a must try!!!! We want to come back to order more cocktails...they all are unique and the presentation is top notch!!!

A very fun place. It IS pricey! I'm not going to drop stars for that.

I wasn't very into the single cocktails, but once we got a table and ordered the "Zombie Punch" I was very into this place. They have a schtick and they do it well. I recommend going straight for group drinks if you have the luxury of being at a table - we had to do our first round at the bar while we waited.

No food for us, but this was a really nice place to meet up with friends and definitely a fun place for an out of towner.

Cool spot to come once or twice for funky drinks and decent jams. Make reservations and save yourself some time. Unless of course, you like to wait in an alley at midnight.  Whatever you dig, man. Later in the evening everyoneisthisclosetogether and it takes 20 mins to get a drink.  So order two.

I've been itching to go here for the longest time and I definitely wasn't disappointed. Drinks were $13 but they were worth it - strong, tasty and presented beautifully. The menu has pictures next to each drink indicating how it'll be served, so you can order solely based off the appearance of your drink (which I unapologetically did).

The bar is located down an alley, so it can be a little difficult to find. Once we got there, we realized there was a line to get in but after asking around, everyone said the line was moving quickly. They were right and we got in after about 20 minutes (on a Saturday night). It did take us forever to get drinks, but you can't be upset because they were carefully and beautifully crafted. The bar wasn't that crowded, which was great. Next time I'll make a reservation but for a first try, I loved it!! Will definitely be returning.

I dropped in with a few co-workers for an early happy hour and was basically like walking into a cave, it's so dark in there... to the point where it was disorienting to leave while the sun was still out.

The drinks are unique but a lot sweeter than I tend to like and relatively pricey.

Overall a fun and different experience, but wouldn't be my first choice for a night out.

I had been anxiously awaiting a trip to Three Dots and a Dash FOREVER. I'm old and not very hip anymore, so I made a res on Open Table so I would be guaranteed a table and an enjoyable experience!

We arrived at 7:30 on a Saturday night and I definitely got lost trying to find the cool, secret alleyway entrance. When we finally got inside, I geeked out over the blue-lit wall of skulls in the entrance and the overall not at all tacky decor despite a potentially tacky theme. We were seated right away at a half-circle booth along the wall of the bar and dug into the menu to decide on drinks.

I began with the Jet Pilot, which I chose because it had grapefruit and lime. Admittedly, I didn't love it. The cinnamon was super powerful in it and the drink was exceptionally boozy. But the presentation was deeeeelightful and I was intrigued enough to try more. My next drink was the "Cacchen Some Rays," which I chose because it had cold brew coffee in it, even though the rest of my party thought I was crazy to order a drink filled with coffee, tequila, rum, passion fruit, lime, and pineapple, it was strangely delicious! All of those seemingly clashing flavors melded together into a sweet, caramelly, complex drink. My final beverage was the Demarara Dry Float, a sweet, floral concoction that was easily the most drinkable of my choices and I would definitely order again. Some of my favorites from around the table were the Saturn, which tasted like an amped up Tom Collins, and the banana daiquiri, which was sweet and decadent.

Though the drinks were fun, the food was AMAZING. Having perused the menu prior to arriving, I knew that they offered mostly small plate type snacks and the food was not the main focus of our visit, but it was incredible! We began with luau chips and guac. The chips are thick, almost chewy, fried bits of guacamole-holding deliciousness. We also got the Thai fried chicken, a sweet and spicy bowl of chicken morsels doused in addicting sauce, the tuna crisp which was a refreshing bowl of fresh tuna pieces tossed with an avocado cream and served with chips, and the pork belly buns which, albeit small, were incredibly delicious, perfectly decadent, wonderfully flavored, and addicting. I could have eaten about fifty of them.

After a few rounds of drinks and many small plates of food, we left around 10:30 and found an incredibly long line waiting to get in and enjoy the tiki-wonderment of Three Dots and a Dash. I think a reservation is the way to go if you're not good at bouncer shmoozing or incredibly patient.

Oh, and as if all this skull-filled, fun-cocktailed, tasty-bites fun isn't enough, meander out of the alley and head to firecakes - open till midnight - and grab yourself a donut. What better to wash down (and reinforce) a night of tropical debauchery?

pics.caption: Demara Dry Float - my fave drink of the night!

review.des:
Oh my gosh! This place is amazing! I had such a blast here. Talk about crazy, fun, creative drinks. I came here for my friends bachelorette party and we had the best time. It was the perfect place to celebrate. They have drinks you can split between many or get a smaller drink. Although by smaller, I would still say it is definitely shareable. Plus the music and the decor were so fun. It was a great place to kick off the evening!

Tip: call ahead and make a reservation for a line jump! The line was crazy long but we did this and it was key! Got right in and they sat us in a cute corner booth.

I found Three Dots and a Dash on my Yelp app. I stopped by for a drink while visiting Chicago. The entrance is located in an alley. Three Dots and a Dash has a romantic ambience. It's best to make reservations if you want a table. The entire place was very busy. Most tables were reserved and the bar area was crowded. We got on the waiting list,a staff member text you once your table is ready.The cocktail menu has a variety of drinks.They put drinks in cool glasses. My drink was average at best in my opinion. It may have been what I ordered. I expected more given the price point. I would be back to try other items on the menu. The staff was very polite and professional. Three Dots and a Dash is a cool place to socialize with a drink in Chicago. I recommend making reservations, so you're not waiting a long time for a table. I give Three Dots and a Dash a 3.5 rating on my first visit.

I was really excited to finally make it to the famous Three Dots and Dash. Definitely make a reservation, a group of us arrived around 9PM on a Thursday and had to wait awhile for a table. The staff wasn't overly friendly either. The atmosphere is cool, so hot in there when it was summer still in Chicago. I have heard they keep the temps extra warm in the winter though to have the tiki vibe. Interior is small and pretty intimate. Drinks are VERY strong, I didn't enjoy the "three dots and a dash" drink. However, the drinks are all cute and fun though.

I am not sure I will be back anytime soon. Glad to check it off my list!

I am absolutely in LOVE with this place. My boyfriend and I went here to celebrate my new job and a successful week in general and had a fabulous time. First of all, they now take reservations, which is excellent. We went in at 8:00pm and had a prime table right at the bar in the main room. I love the decor here and that it's underground as well, it gives it a very cool feeling-a cross between a club and a beach bar that you'd find in the Caribbean. The tables are decorated with fishbowl centerpieces with miniature "beach scopes" in them, so cute.

Our server was fantastic with recommendations and was efficient and kind. I would recommend any of the drinks, but I love the traditional Pua Pua Punch, it's simple, fruity, and just what you'd picture drinking at the beach. Be warned that all the drinks are strong, I had two and was pretty tipsy (okay, beyond tipsy). Our server was great with refilling our waters and even suggested that "water is your best friend after two of those drinks"! Although I didn't like the actual drink, I loved the dolphin banana garnish on the banana Daiquiri. I believe there is a photo of me kissing said dolphin floating around of instagram and Yelp...

The food here is great too, surprising so as the drinks are more touted than anything else. I loved the pineapple guacamole with luau chips and the pork buns were second to Sunda's. We also got the coconut shrimp and the Thai chicken skewers-both of which were flavorful and went great with our tiki drinks. I would recommend this place for a date, group outing, birthday celebrations, and honestly anything else. If you want a table, make sure and make a reservation as all of the tables are already reserved and the bar becomes standing room only very quickly. When we left around 10:30pm there was a line to get in, which is a little ridiculous seeing as it's not even a club, but it feels like one and is apparently garnering quite the panache about town. I hear that Kate Upton celebrated her last birthday here, so you know it's cool.

pics.caption: A dolphin banana-exactly what every drink needs

review.des:
To be quite frank, this is one of my favorite bars I've been to in Chicago. Whether it was the ambience, luck of the night, the drinks/food or the people I was with--who knows? But we had a kickass time

While some people may think the whole tiki theme is a bit overdone and somewhat cheesy, Three Dots and a Dash makes it downright fun and enjoyable. While the ambience is a bit dim, there's some funky purple mood lighting that keeps it a bit uplifting. Combine that with the fun tiki bar, friendly servers and enthusiastic bartenders and you've got a recipe for success.

Be wary--the drinks are strong, but delicious so it can be easy to polish off a few before even realizing. All the basic cocktails are $13 (yes, a tad pricey), but based on all the TLC (tender love and care) that goes into crafting each cocktail, I let it slide

The Jet Pilot, Zombie Punch and Dead Reckoning were my favorites among the ones we ordered. But if you're with a large group, you might want to cut the cocktails and order one of the big punch bowls to split

All in all, a great little bar to visit at the beginning of the night if you're in town visiting. Just be wary that the food and drinks don't come cheap
So amazing!! In the basement through the alley, we had the banana drink and the coconut .. for food we had the pu pu platter which is great and the tuna poke, my personal favorite !!
Atmosphere and drinks were terrific.  Service was just okay.  Waitress barely looked at us when ordering, delivering food and the check.

Three Dots and a Dash is haunted by tiki mixology penchant for taking FOREVER to make cocktails. The night I visited, the guy behind the bar had to be either new, a bar-back covering someone's break, completely untrained or a hipster d-bag who just didn't care because he was moving comically slow. It's Saturday night, who has time for a guy to take 20 minutes (literally not figuratively) to make 2 Mai Tai's?

It was actually kind of funny because after about 10 minutes I just offered him a $50 bill for "however many beers that buys me," but he was way too cool for school to even acknowledge me. As he went on building these ridiculous cocktails the line just got deeper and deeper. When he finally finished he presented them to the two patrons like they were golden cocktails mined from King Tut's tomb and added that they were mai tai's. Seriously, mai tai's? Like not even your proprietary, 37 ingredient, secret 3-dot brew .. a Mai Tai, a drink that's 60 years old?

It probably didn't help that we had had a tremendous evening at the far superior tiki bar Lost Lake (which i think has since burned down?!) the night before or one of the highlight evenings of my drinking career at Aviary the next night. I can see why this place is a hit with the bridge and tunnel crowd who don't mind paying extra for less and for whom tiki is still a novelty. If that's not you, go elsewhere.

I'm enamored with Three Dots and a Dash.  Came here on a Friday night around 12:30 and only had to wait ~10 minutes to get in.  The alleyway torches and short line forming outside only added to the mystique and intrigue of this place.  Once we got in, my party was not disappointed.  A flight of stairs leading underneath a backlit wall of skulls was an excellent start, and it only got better from there.

The Polynesian theme runs rampant, from the food to the drinks to the interior decor to what the (exceptionally cute) waitresses were wearing.  Cocktails are upwards of $13 and are well worth it--strong, tasty, creative, and visually spectacular!  They have a different mug (skull, coconut, easter island head, etc) for every drink on their menu!  Despite what some other reviewers have said, we sat ourselves at a booth and received service rather quickly.  The DJ played some excellent tunes, from reggaeton to chillstep and some deep house, not the same old top 40's shit that you hear everywhere else.....this was a welcome change from nearly every other bar deejay that exists.  The bathroom had all kinds of cologne, mints, and a friendly attendant--a nice touch.

Bring a date here if you're looking to 'seal the deal'; the combination of dim lighting, cozy seating areas, downtempo music, strong tropical drinks and general cool underground ambiance should be enough to make even the most conservative guy or girl yearn to play a game of hide the salami.  70% of the time, it works every time.

I can't wait to return in the hopes that maybe one day I'll earn enough to splurge on their fabled 'Treasure Chest #1': a smoking/flaming mega-cocktail that's served with a bottle of Dom Perignon.  In short, if Yelp allowed 6 stars to be given, " . . . & a -- " would be most deserving of it.  Without a doubt one of the coolest bars I've ever set foot in.

pics.caption: The Jet Pilot....three different kinds of rum! Strong.

review.des: After venturing down an alley and trying an unmarked door, we made our way downstairs and to the bar for a few drinks. Fun atmosphere, very creative looking drinks, but not so tasty.  We tried Three Dots and a Dash, Crocodile Tuesday, and another drink. All three had a lot of alcohol in them, so if that's what you are looking for, then look no more. For tasty drinks, though, go elsewhere. My friend commented that her drink tasted like a band-aid, and the mint in two of the drinks was overpowering. The bar area was very crowded. Glad we tried it, but there are so many better places in Chicago.

Wow, what can we say other than.......WOW! We came here while visiting my sister and her family during our anniversary in May. My niece made reservations to take us here and we were not let down. The drinks are definitely on the strong side and pretty wild if you ask me. We had drinks out of skulls, clam shells, and pineapples. I think there were some other shapes in there as well but we got pretty buzzed to say the least. The entrance is very unassuming but upon entering you will be amazed. I can say this is a must stop, see, and experience destination in Chicago.

Having visited so many tiki bars (WE LOVE THEM) this one is for sure appealing to the younger preppy crowd. While it's well done and all it just doesn't have the full laid back feel of a true "cheesy" tiki bar. Also it's pretty pricey and I can't say it was above and beyond. Food was good but just overall not the true classic tiki bars. I get it's in the trendy area and that's what they went for.

My work friend had heard about this place so we wanted to check it out before dinner and the after work crowd. We got lost at first because the place is unmarked and the entrance is in the alley. As you descend down the stairs you walk past a wall of skills which I liked. However, the moment you reach the hostess desk things change to a tropical theme. I really hate places that are pretentious for no reason. The hostess was rude and short with us and pointed to the bar in the back. We asked for a table and were told they were all reserved. So we went to the bar and got a huge tropical drink on fire and one in a shell. The drinks were what you would expect. The place got overcrowded really fast...but there were plenty of tables open 2 hours later. I have no desire to return here or take any tourists or friends.

Overcrowded rude did not give table drink large and fancy but not enough to return

It's hidden in an alley. It's underground. It's got a guy behind a velvet rope at the door. It's got stairs so dark you can hardly see your feet. It's got a bearded hipster in suspenders and a fauxhawk waiting to greet you. It's got many, many hip patrons sitting in a dark, dark, DARK tiki-themed subterranean cavern, all screaming to each other to be heard over the other hip screamers. In short, it's so impossibly trendy that "trendy" doesn't do it justice.

Oh, and if you can make out the faint outlines of your menu under the glow of your phone screen, you can order strong tiki drinks at strong tiki prices, and eat a handful of reasonably tasty small-plate tiki snacks, and derive great tiki entertainment from the many hip conversations being shouted all around you.

Love this place, but it can be a real pain to get in and reservations usually fill up quite quickly. The drinks are amazing and so is the food. A little bummed they pulled the papaya salad from the menu as it is one of our favorites.

Literally all of the appeal of Three Dots is the atmosphere. The theater of the experience is rad but the main thing to know is that the drinks are pretty pricey at around $12-$25 per drink. It's def something to check out when you get out to Chicago for sure, but I'd advise you to make a reservation. The drinks aren't very big, but the elaborate ceramic tiki cups are and they get real heavy, real quick. There aren't many nooks provided to set your drink down, and finding a table is impossible because they are all reserved. My only real issue was that everyone that worked there was rude, starting with the guy at the front door. To purchase a cup took a while, and was a big "to-do" from ask to finalization. Apparently, they use to be available for purchase online but that's no longer an option. Bummer, I'd love another cup but I doubt I'll bother coming in again.

I have been going to this place since it first open and it is sooo cute :) Three Dots in a Dash is located right behind bub city. Note your not going to see a sign or anything and you go down an alley to enter. The line can be long at times especially at night, but the drinks are worth it.

I prefer drinks on the sweeter side so I would recommend Banana Daiquiri. I love how the waitress had the bananas shaped like dolphins. It doesn't take much to make me happy. :) They also have ridiculously large drinks for sharing that serve 3 or more (need to try that next time)

In terms of food there's very limited choices but I did like the Crab Rangoon and the Coconut Shrimp. This place is crowded, but the music selections are good and keep every body happy. This place is a must visit. For around $20 you can even buy the cool mugs/cups your drink is served in, which I was tempted to do, but came to my senses and realized I would probably never use it. Lol

I was finally in the area and decided to stop by to grab a drink before dinner. It was around 6pm on a Friday and just about all the bar stools were taken up, but plenty of tables were available. We opted for the last 2 spots at the bar since we were just getting a drink. This place is pretty over the top, decor and music. I had the missionary's downfall and my cousin got the three dots and a dash. Presentation was fun, but we both thought the drinks were a little too sweet. It was an okay experience up until a big decorative metal pineapple fell from it's pedestal, crashed and shattered a big glass bowl filled with some type of liquid concoction, and spilled all over the bar and also onto my cousin's outfit. There were also a few pieces of glass on her. No one asked if we were okay or needed anything. I had to ask for a napkin like 3 times, no one was paying attention to us. Unfortunately, this happened right after I finished paying the bill. Not cool!

pics.caption: Three dots and a dash and the missionary's downfall

review.des:
So, I came back after making a reservation and was very disappointed. First, there was absolutely no point in making a reservation.  I arrived at 845pm for my 9pm reservation, and at 930 finally asked what the deal was-
And was told it would be another 45 minutes (that's 1hr15 mins past my
Reservation time). Apparently they overbook their reservations and don't seem to care if you make one or not. This is very much a change from last time i was here, and this will definitely be the last time I come in.

Three Dots and a Dash is one of my all time favorite places in Chicago! I love the tiki vibe, and you can tell that they put a lot of time and attention into the decor and ambiance of the place.  You enter through the alley behind Bub City, and it feels like you are going to a secret bar. Until you see the tiki torches, and depending on the time of night, the long line!  They started taking reservations on open table, but it can be difficult to get one. I recommend just getting there a little early and the wait usually isn't too terrible.

My biggest complaint is that if you do end up having to wait, the bar is usually pretty slammed and it can be difficult to find a place to stand let alone get a drink. So unless you are prepared to deal with some crowds, try to get one of those reservations or just come in a bit early - like around 6 or 7. You wont regret settling in at a table.

The bar tenders here put in work! All of these drinks have crazy garnishes, and you can tell that each drink itself takes some time and effort to make. I have a lot of favorites here, but I love Bunni's Banana Daiquiri, the Mai Tai, and the Painkiller.  There are also some really fun punches that you can order for a group to share.

They also have great snacks.  My favorites are the Thai Fried Chicken, Coconut Shrimp and Crab Rangoon. But you can't really go wrong.

pics.caption: Mix of fun tiki drinks for our group.

review.des:
Fantastic tailored cocktails.  This place is huge on mixology.  Their drinks are stiff, and dangerous because they are so delicious.  Presentation is amazing.  Service is modest.  However, this place gets crowded like a public pool on a hot California day.  Would really recommend this place is drinks if you forte.  However, on any given weekend, expect to be standing and bumping elbows.  

PROTIP:  Avoid this place like the plague if you see a line.  Reservations highly recommended if you would like a place to sit.

I've been wanting to check this place out for ages, so I was pretty excited when I went with a group of friends here. There were 6 of us total, and we actually got in without any wait whatsoever. And this was around 11:45 on a Friday night. The atmosphere inside was pretty cute and I loved the decorations. Maybe it's because we were in a dancing mood, but it was kinda disappointing that there wasn't really a dance floor. The music was aight, again nothing special.

As for the drinks, they are pretty pricey. I got the drink with the banana dolphin (I don't remember the name) and that was decent. It was really strong, but still sweet. My friends didn't enjoy their drinks, however. The taste of rum was overwhelming, and just not really well mixed.

So all in all, don't think it's really worth the money. But hey, if you like pretty drinks, then this is the place to go.

Lines, lines everywhere!

First line starts outside in the alley. There were probably 20 people ahead of us in line and we waited maybe about 30 minutes. Not terrible, but just be prepared. There is an option to make reservations- not sure if there's a minimum number or what the parameters are for reservations, but I would look into it.

Second line is waiting for drinks. These drinks are very intricate with all the ingredients and the beautiful garnish, so I understand why they take so long, but I still don't like waiting 20+ minutes for a drink. These drinks are beautiful when they're finally ready, and they definitely have a lot of alcohol in them. There are even some drinks on the menu with a skull and cross bones next to them indicating HIGH alcohol content. I got the painkiller No.639 and my boyfriend got the 3 dots and a dash. I definitely liked his better because it wasn't very sweet and has a nice flavor with all the spices added. The coconut cream just made the painkiller a little too sweet for my tastes.

The decor here is obviously tiki themed, and it's pretty dark inside. There's a dj booth, so you'll have loud music all night. It gets super crowded inside and there's not really any place to set your drink down unless you have a table reserved. The drink was so beautifully made, I felt like I should sit down and really enjoy it, but that unfortunately wasn't possible.

We decided to stop by Three Dots and a Dash for drinks based on a friend's recommendation. Not knowing what we were in for, we walked up and down Hubbard St twice before realizing it was in the back alley with a subtle sign above the bright blue door. As we made our way down the stairs, we were greeted with a wall of skulls before stepping into the tiki oasis. If you're looking for a tropical escape from the busy city life, this is the place to go!

I got the Polynesian Pearl Diver, a smooth blend of scotch, butter (!), and cinnamon. My boyfriend got the Western Sour, a bourbon with a citrusy twist. Both drinks not only tasted great (and strong) but also were visually stunning! The attention to detail was impeccable - intricate mugs adorned with flowers, fruit slices, cinnamon stick, umbrellas, and even a mermaid swizzler stick. We arrived just after they opened, so it was relatively empty at the time. We were able to chat with the bartenders, who were very friendly and attentive. It does get pretty crowded later at night, so if you're looking for a more chill time, go early.

We were too full to try the food but the menu looked delicious. Overall, it was a little pricier but the experience makes up for it.

Fantastic location, off the beaten path (slightly). Danny was our bartender and did a FANTASTIC job! He was personable and very responsive! The drinks are fairly pricey, and really don't have much volume - but the presentation was fabulous. You're paying more for the ambiance, but it is a fun time.

My friend and I had the Bikini After Dark and Saturn. Both very tasty! Then Bartender Danny gave us an Octopus - also quite tasty! Worth a trip!!

Really true to it's theme and really tasty (strong) drinks. The bar has been packed every time I've come in, however, and the drinks are always packed with ice. I recommend reserving a table online ahead of time- standing room gets really crowded really quickly.

I love fancy cocktails, and if you do, too, this place is for you. And if you like Tiki and sweet cocktails, this place is definitely for you. If you can, make a reservation or go early as it's hard to get in as the night progresses. Also, it's not cheap (as cocktails go), and you'll want to drink them all! They do have great Polynesian bar snacks to accompany your cocktails, and that's always a plus!
Feelin' like I'm in the tropics, good vibes. Until I go outside and it's freezing/snowing/raining/gloomy/dark/itsasundayand­ihaveworktomorrow

Everyone needs to get over the "sketchy" entrance.  It's like everyone in Chicago is a transplant from Wisconsin or Minnesota these days. Grow up, weirdos. If you get shanked in River North, you deserve it. I put that Mayor Daley.

Everyone has been really first class here.  I appreciate the hospitality for sure.

The drinks, for obvious reason, take a bit of time to make. People need to learn to keep their pants on, because good things come to those who wait.

The downside:

Expect waking up feeling like you ate your whole bag of Halloween candy. The whole next day I was having tremors, and people were looking at me funny while I was trying to do my thing in these streets.

It was 17° people. But one of Indy's best bartenders recommended we pay Three Dots and a Dash a visit - if you knew this guy, you wouldn't opt for a Plan B no matter how damn cold that line may be. We waited for at least 15 minutes outside in the back alley. Several visitors arrived at the front "desk" to try and weasel their platform stiletto selves in ahead of the masses - failure, failure, failure. (hallelujah, amiright?)

Once we finally made it inside we could visually see why Ziggy (the bartender) recommended that we add this bar to our Chicago lineup. My first reaction was "tiki bar in basement of Chicago building - - wtf?" But when it's 17 degrees outside and snow is on the ground, how can you complain about a mini tango with tropical paradise? Visual: tropical floral dresses on waitresses, wrap around booths, weird kitschy centerpieces, dark lighting and an abundance of tiki-type grass overhead.  The cherry on top for my visit was hands down the music. A healthy blend of rap from the 90s.

You should know that I'm not one for sweet or Caribbean style cocktails so the bebidas here really didn't do it for me. Our table of five sampled 5 different cocktails - I'm thinking my banana daiquiri was the best option. I would definitely visit again for the vibe of this bar but not so much for the cocktails at $13 a pop it was hard to swallow the sweetness and the price all at once. **Kudos to Three Dots for making some of the prettiest bebidas I've ever encountered - come on, would ya look at that banana dolphin? Adorable.

One more note, they also have a creative small plate menu if you're craving a late night eat with that pretty cocktail of yours.

IMA visits Chicago.  

Three Dots and a Dash is an amazingly cool tiki bar on the north side of the river in Chicago. Each of the tropical drinks comes in a unique glass that makes every order feel special.  The lighting, music, and ambiance is totally on point.  This place appears be wildly successful and for good reason.  Right near all the Rick Bayless restaurants (down an ally to get in), this is a must stop in Chicago if you enjoy a fun cocktail.  

the bar staff was very friendly as well, rare at a hot spot.

Tiki-time Chicago Style

Lettuce Entertain you a Mai Tai or two. If you have three, you will have difficulty writing the review because 1.) not only will you probably have been there awhile  - and by then, you will have ordered some Thai chicken wings & ps - they serve food week nights 'til past midnight (I think that's like 4pm in the South Pacific) but 2.) you are probably going to go home with some very hot out-of-town dude. OK, whoa, wait...

I'll come back to this one ;)

pics.caption: Tiki take home (leftover Thai chix & color)

review.des:
For some reason, my significant other loves, loves, loves tiki bars. So, almost immediately after my arrival in Chicago, I was on the hunt for one to take him to as a way of thanking him for driving a U-Haul full of my stuff to downtown Chicago.

I made a reservation on Opentable for a Sunday night at 7pm. The bar was full, but there were plenty of empty tables available.

First of all, as you can tell from the pictures on Yelp, their drinks are super Instagram worthy! But more importantly, the drinks not only looked good, they tasted good. I had the Pandan Pain Killer which I would highly recommend if you love coconut as much as I do. He ordered the Tropical Itch and the Saturn. Most cocktails were $13-$15 each, which is what I expected for a place like this.

We also shared the $38 pupu platter because we hadn't had dinner yet, and honestly I didn't think I could drink cocktails on an empty stomach. The platter came with meatballs, egg rolls, crispy chicken bites, pork skewers and yucca fries; all with some sort of Asian sauce or seasoning. Be warned that though everything was tasty, it was either very salty, very fried or both. We thought it balanced out the sweetness of the cocktails well, but we probably wouldn't order it again. Especially for the price, we'd grab a nicer meal elsewhere before heading to Three Dots and a Dash for drinks.

A "Hole in the Wall" with Fantastic DRINKS

It is a small venue with a tiki bar theme down the ally but definitely worth the search if want a drink....but I would caution you to drink them slowly because they don't skimp on the alcohol.

We also go a couple appetizers while sipping. The Thai fried chicken was fabulous because it as freshly prepared and the sauce on it was flavorful. The other appetite was the luau chips, which I didn't care for but I don't like fried pork rinds.
Overall, a great experience but I would recommend a reservation.
Went here for a late xmas present.  Atmosphere was great, bartender was super friendly and talkative and the drinka were well worth the price. Such a great time!
Solid and unique cocktails, this is in my top 5 for best cocktail spots although it can get busy, so I suggest going on an off-night.

This is a hidden alley bar with lots to offer. A very unique place in a basement with some of the most unique and strong drinks you can try.

Our bartender Brenda was a rockstar behind the counter. We tried various drinks all with unique and exquisite presentation. Drinking out of a tiki cup was interesting but my wife seemed to love it.

I had the feeling this was a bit more of a girls night out type of a place but I'm not gonna lie my drink was on point. The atmosphere and crowd were all lively and energetic. Decorations are pretty cool and unique. It lives up to its "Tikiness" The drink menu was extensive and I'm looking forward to checking this place out again in the near future.

FYI: drinks are a bit pricey but well worth the after math

As far as Tiki bars go, this is one of the best you can find in the city!  I have been here three times and have yet to be disappointed.

Everyone talks about how amazing the drinks are, and rightfully so. Each drink is detailed and festive in its presentation, not to mention absolutely delicious! Drinks also tend to be strong, but because they are well mixed, you may not taste it until you are two thirds of the way through your drink! Keep that in mind when you look at the prices, you get a good amount of bang for your buck even though you may be paying more per drink than your average cocktail at a typical River North bar.

What really makes this place special though, is that the level of commitment to the Tiki Bar theme runs strong through all aspects of the experience: decor, lighting, staff, food, and music. The atmosphere is similar to that of a tropical island vacation, in a slightly cheesy but very fun way! If you're here on a date or for dinner with friends (provided you've secured a reservation well in advance), share some small plates, the food goes well with the fruity drinks.

My top three tips: 1) Make a reservation, especially if you're with a group of four or more. 2) Drink your drinks slowly to both enjoy them, and not over indulge yourself 3) Try the food!

Three Dots and a Hangover, as many call it, is a solid tiki bar. Often overly packed in the bar however, and I've never been sat at a table after waiting a long time when I could clearly see empty tables. Nice bartenders, but the host staff has proved kind of useless. The drinks are guaranteed to give you a hangover and 99% of them have pineapple (probably that canned juice). Put a little more creativity into your drink list!

I was staying with friends for a weekend when this place first opened up. The first time we went, I thought it was really cool because the entrance was in the middle of a dark alley and it felt like you belonged to some secret society going into here. On my next visit, that kind of changed.
This place is a lot of fun, however the staff is super unattentive, can be rude, and the people here act like they have summer homes in the Hamptons. Somehow, my group of 9 managed to get a table that we all squished into and we started ordering drinks. Although they're really good, they're pretty pricey. But that is expected with a location like this. The drinks come in the cutest tiki cups and coconuts with umbrellas to distract you from the 10 degree weather that awaits you outside. The ambiance is really cool and unique. It's dark in here but there are skulls on one wall with lights and Hawaiian shirts on another.
If you're from out of town and want to experience a unique bar, try this place out. It's really fun, considering you're in the middle of Chiberia. I can't wait to come back.

I sure do love this place, and obviously a "must see" for you fellow tikifiles.  Too bad the patrons don't join in the fun - not an Aloha shirt in sight.  Good customer service, great drinks, good enough food.  The best Pain Killer I've ever had. Make sure to buy the mug!
Mediocre, overpriced cocktails. Not sure what they are trying to accomplish with the drink menu.

Three Dots and a Dash is one of my favorite spots in River North! Great people and amazing cocktails. The bartenders know their stuff and make the experience quite enjoyable. I stayed at the Kinzie hotel which is right down the street for a week for business and i would enjoy a few drinks after each day. Love the place and i'm always telling people to go there!

Love this place & the tiki themed feel. The tropical drinks are tasty and unique but little pricey. I love the cool, dark atmosphere.
I didn't have the food there so I can't say how good the food truly is. But Three Dots and a Dash is quite the experience when in Chicago!

I'm a big fan of lounges and this definitely qualifies as that. There isn't an area to dance and the music isn't loud to the point where you can't hold a conversation with the person next to you.

Decorations and style is that of a hawaiian tiki lounge. More importantly, the drinks are fabulous. Strong, semi-expensive, and I can easily say that the alcohol taste is masked. They also have some specialty drinks like this huge treasure chest that one of the tables next to us got.

P.S. Entrance is sort of hidden since it's in an alleyway.

pics.caption: Fancy smancy drinks. 13 bucks a pop

review.des:
First time here, I couldn't find the place; it was down the ally. I've been here for date night, 2 bday gatherings, and just for a girls night out. First time was the coolest thing ever. The drinks came in these cool cups, all different. There were so GOOD!! I've tried the food once. It was ok. Nothing to write home about...but the drinks though. WOW. They may seem fruity at first but geesh they can knock you off your feet. Bartenders are friendly and servers are just as friendly.

Scary story...across the street was an old prison and lots of spooky stories. If you have to wait in line, maybe the bouncer will tell you about them.

If your looking for a good drink, a great atmosphere, friendly staff, some place different, check this place out.

Upscale tiki bar. Drinks are pricey, but worth it. They make the pretty strong to make you feel like you weren't getting shafted too much. They also look good! Good experience and great ambiance. This is one of the go to spots when I need to entertain out of town guests.
They nerfed the drink menu. Drinks are smaller and less alcoholic now (but the same price). I'll still come back, but not as often.
Highly enjoyable. Drinks are top notch. Has a slight attitude about itself wtr seating ... but just hover around the bar until you can get a stool. The next drink will be even better.

Let me preface this interview by saying that I spent most of my time in this bar half-asleep, not because it was boring but because I was so tired that nothing beyond a megaphone and a can of red bull could have kept me awake. That said, Three Dots and a Dash has a great atmosphere, and showing up at 12:30am on a Sunday Night, there it was incredibly relaxed, incredibly casual, but also incredibly cool. Premium Tiki bar feel, completely with cool blue/green lighting, vestiges of bamboo and tropical garb, and of course a wall of 100+ types of rum.  

The big thing here is the group drinks, and looking at the menu everything cocktail seems uniquely crafted with it's own special features. For example, there was the Zombie Punch which comes in a skull cup and is lit on fire, or what we ordered being the Pieces of 8 which came with in a giant oyster(?) mold with straws for all 7 of us. Rum, Passion Fruit, Lemon, it was pretty tasty but the drinks they make here are otherwise pretty strong. Granted these aren't cheap($13 a cocktail, the grouop drinks are usually a little less per person), but a great scene to visit and certainly try out.

Also, our server was THE nicest server I have ever had at a bar. Incredibly helpful with our drink orders, very patient even though we were new, and also willing to take time and talk to us about what else to do and where else to go in Chicago. Recommendations have been taken firmly into account, and Three Dots and a Dash is certainly on that list.

Great waitstaff, tasty food and drinks. But, this place isn't so new anymore, and the faux-exclusivity is a little tiring on a Wednesday at 6:30pm.

Didn't have a reservation for a party of 7 (I'll admit, a little large) but it wasn't too crowded. We were seated when more of our party showed up, but told we'd have to give up our table at 7pm or 7:15pm. Ooook, fair enough...but sort of felt like an empty threat. And it was; we never heard about that again and stayed til 8:30.

Additionally, I threw back 3 cocktails, ate some light food, and left maybe tipsy at best. I recall the drinks being dangerously potent before...and now $40 gets you a little tipsy here.

So to conclude, the drinks are weaker, the attitude is just as frosty, but with less of a crowd. It's still a really pretty inside, and the waitstaff is nice, but probably more of a once-in-a-while type bar or somewhere to take tourists. I'll be writing a similar but way more positive review about Violet Hour soon; now THAT is how you handle the transition from super new/trendy to a unique/stylish part of the neighborhood.

Great atmosphere!! Came here on a Monday at 530pm- not busy at all. But I know it's usually pretty packed. Great after work spot for a drink or to show friends! The entrance is in a back alley so make sure to google it and look for the ID checker guy. The drinks are around $14-16 each and are SUPER cool! I asked the bartender for a recommendation and she let me try a little taster of the one I was interested in, just so I'd know I liked it! So great of a location- but it's dark so keep that in mind if your bringing friends!
Really excited when I got there, really. REALLY disappointed when I tasted my drink. Way to ruin some perfectly good rum.
great date spot.  decent appetizer menu... tasty drinks... a bit pricey but comes with the territory.

A+ for providing a totally unique experience! Came here during my bachelorette party and we got the dry ice smoking, rum punch treasure chest. AWESOME!! Totally did not expect for our server to bring us this smoking chest of goodness.

The interior of this place is just fun, and is a perfect place for a bachelorette party or any other celebration.  I can't speak to the prices as I didn't pay, but can imagine all this fun comes with a hefty price tag.

Was glad to experience it though!

So... i get the hype but don't agree.

Traveling from out of town on 4th of July weekend. Saw good reviews. My first impression was a rude bouncer. I walked up to ask what dress code is (we got in town late,  wearing shorts) and before i could open my mouth "line is back there, bud." Am i just spoiled  with Texan hospitality?

No tables so ordered from the bar.yea drinks are fancy but 45min wait for a drink. I stood at the bar while everyone around me got served. I waited patiently with a smile about 15min then started trying to wave down and call the bartender, continued to be ignored. The female that made my drink was so focused making drinks didn't say a word to me.

The floor was very sticky.

I ordered the poblano (i like poblano) and it was awful.  I never send drinks back, but a $15+ drink and 45min of waiting i asked for something else. My gfs drink was much better.

All in all the horrible wait and being ignored a at the bar is reason for 1 star.
This place is the bomb!  Great cocktails and food.  Pu Pu  platter is great with super strong cocktails.  Service was great and no wait with reservation.

pics.caption: This place is awesome for island cocktails and food!  Love it!!!

review.des: I love this bar!! I've been many times. Drinks are very pricey, but it's a fun treat!! Staff is awesome & kind.
Beautiful and tasty drinks. Requires reservation. Environment is very pleasant and service is good.

Came her the day before the 4th. Had great time with friends. Ordered a Bali bowl that had smoke coming out of it. Said server 5-6 people but we are alcoholics so it only served 3 of us and we got a round of individual cases. My friend had the missionary's downfall and that was my favorite. Fun atmosphere and great service!
The venue was out of this world. Amazing Cocktails. For a place so crowded, I expected slow service but our drinks came less than 3 minutes after we ordered them. I'm very impressed.

After dinner drinks ...have been wanting to visit and it didn't disappoint. It's definitely a reservation place as there were no tables available but as luck would have it, 10 minutes into waiting at the bar (the time it took to place our order and get our drinks) we were able to secure stools at the bar. The bartender was awesome, explained the drinks and gave us some history on the meaning of Three dots and a dash...distilleries and nitrogen, who knew this experience would leave me wanting to learn more! I wish I would have caught our bartender's name. Can't wait to go back randomly.

My coworkers made fun of me when my first reaction to this place was about how clean it was. As a speakeasy, three dots and a dash was not super crowded and made you feel like you were partying in Hawaaaiii.

The drinks come in cool looking mugs or bowls and all have a tropical flare to them. Looots of options for rum lovers. The drinks with a little skull icon next to it are supposed to be stronger (although I think they're just) so pick and choose what works for you!

It might be a little hard to find this place as first because it's tucked away in a little alley, but all you gotta do is follow the blue light. Once you see the blue light you'll know you're getting closer to paradise!

Three Dots and a Dash is THEE place to take your out of town friends or colleagues during a week night. Weekends can yield extremely long waits, outside, in an alley. If you want someplace, unique, fun, downtown, and slightly upscale this place is worth wait! I first went here on my birthday and had a blast! The atmosphere is dark, candle lit, and ambient. You could easily lose track of time there because you don't see many people on their phones, most are enjoying the company or aahing over a flaming cocktail! Located in a back alley off of Clark St. you really find a gem in their custom tiki cups, flaming drinks, and tiki eats such as pork belly bites or sauce drenched chicken. :) Bring your friends here for a real hawaiin night on the town!
So fun in this bungalow! Entertaining, but be ready to wait in line to get in and at the bar.

This is one of the most unique places in Chicago. I love taking a new person here and seeing their face when we enter the building through the alley and descend the stairs under a wall of skulls. The drinks are expensive and take forever to get, but they're worth a thousand Instagram pictures.

While it's kind of cliche to go to a bar that's down an alley, its definitely worth it once you try. There is a fine selection of rum based drinks that are served up in a fun and friendly tiki atmosphere. The crab rangoons were made with blue crab and tasted great. The background music was a nice upbeat chill. There were plenty of people there on a Monday when we went.

pics.caption: Bunny's Banana Daiquiri with a dolphin banana sculpture.

review.des: Great bar!! Visited from California. Loved the drinks and the service was outstanding. Shout out to our bartender Aiden (did I spell that right? ) Not only was he friendly, but we were visiting from California and he took the  time to suggest places for us to go to, and was insanely patient with some guy asking a million questions. I was a bartender for years and wouldn't have been able to do that.

This place has some amazing drinks. They're strong and good. The food is also great. I had a couple of things: the peanut shrimp, thai chicken, the broccoli, chicken curry skewers, coconut chicken...not a single complaint about any of them! All great. I also had the mango sorbet for dessert and it was great. As for the drinks, I got to try the mai tai (pretty strong) and the western sour. If you like whiskey sours, you'll like the western sour. I also had a treasure chest...if you're planning on getting that make sure you have at least four people in your party because they are never ending! They taste pretty much just like a fishbowl but definitely one of the coolest things to get on the menu.

The overall vibe of the place was great as well, dimmed lights, very modern. They have a coat check as well.

Amazing spot. Very chill atmosphere. Staff is on point. Our bartender Ivana was very sweet and knowledgeable about the drink menu. She made us a killer cocktail that left me speechless. We will definitely be back for more!

Over-rated tiki bar.  The drinks are good but pretty expensive.  If you feel like you have to go, make a reservation or go on an off-night otherwise you'll be waiting in a line outside then waiting in line for a drink or waiting at a table for a drink.  The only reason we went and were able to get drinks and a table is because my friend knew one of the bartenders, yet we still had to wait.  

I will most likely not be returning, as there are so many other bars with better service, shorter waits, aren't nearly as crowded and have affordable drinks.  But if that's not your jam, give this place a try.

Tons of fun here on our pasty expats' tour of hipster Chicago.  

We were the proverbial early birds here on a weekday evening: Half-full when we arrived; a few groups of young pros and frat boys had filled up most of the spots by the time we finished our two rounds. I imagine the vibe changes considerably as the night wears on.  

Yes, it's an underground Tiki bar 1000 miles from the nearest ocean.  Much is made of the vaunted "Tiki culture" (which itself is faux-island kitsch but at least originated NEAR the Pacific).  Every cocktail has lots of ingredients and comes in a different sort of vessel, and will set you back the price of a movie ticket.  We had some apps none of which stick in the mind one way or another.  

The whole thing is quite Disney-esque but enjoyable; would bring friends here but couldn't see the point of being a "regular".

Ok, Ive been to the Violet Hour, I hate that place, pretentious as hell, what a load of crap. Three Dots and a Dash is what the Violet Hour wants to be, not crappy and and actually cool. If you want a fancy tropical cocktail and you are downtown, get your keester in here and order a Zombie.

You have to enter through the back alley, which seems kinda pretentious, however its not because you walk past a wall of glowing SKULLS, its awesome. The violet hour makes you wait unnecessarily in a lobby constructed of old plywood, which is LAME. Sorry to compare the two, but my point is that Three Dots and a Dash is GREAT, if you want a fancy cocktail come in here, its awesome, just like when you are in a tropical area and you are burning up and you want to get the hell away from the sun and suck down some alcohol. Suck up that alcohol.
super pretty ambiance! and very cute drinks! a little too pricy for what you are paying for, but nevertheless worth trying!

Three Dots and a Dash is a VERY trendy Chicago bar.  They make more of "mixology" type drinks.  Each drink is about $16 and is very strong.  They are served in really cool tiki glasses with a bunch of fruit and frill.  

The atmosphere of this basement bar is really neat, they have a tiki type look with skulls and grass skirt covering the entire bar.  It is a really cool place to see and grab a drink at.  They do have food however if you plan to go on a weekend (probably a Thursday too) you will need reservations.  The line was really long to even get into the bar.  It seems to be the "hot spot" right now.  People were at booths and tables eating.
Let's just say I want here on a first date, the guy didn't make the cut but this place definitely did! The drinks are amazing, the weird way to enter the place was cool, and the atmosphere was fun.

Do you hate money and love pretentiousness? Then 3 Thots and a Dash is for you.

The Dash must be for Stacey Dash... looks great on the outside but Fox News rotten on the inside.

I know there's a drought in CA but didn't know Chicago was also affected by it cuz this place charges heavy for a cup of ice. $15 for ice and a few drops of fruity cocktail at the bottom.

The place was half empty but the host wouldn't allow us to move to a more comfortable booth. I tried to talk to him a second time but he wouldn't look up from his stand, too busy batting his eyes at his own reflection in the mirror. These little boys and their K-Pop dreams....

The decor and space is cool. The blue wall of skulls is cool. But again, let me use Stacey Dash as an example. It's what's on the inside that matters my friends. And the BS pumping at the heart of this joint is gross.

We were going to order some food too but I just couldn't stomach the stuck up vibe and we bounced after our cup of ice.

The bathrooms were super clean tho. So I dropped a deuce and kept it moving.

Don Ho, tiki bars, and fruity umbrella drinks are all cool with me but drop that ho attitude will ya?
There are so many better places to stop by in Chicago.

Lovely drinks! The entrance seemed a bit shady at first given that it wasnt where it says it was and instead was behind the address listed, but just make sure you ask the guy at the front or i guess follow the people lol. Their decor was really chill and Caribbean ish and so were their drinks. Mixed crowd.

Oh and make sure you call ahead to reserve a table! Great services!

Drinks were good, crafted with a lot of attention to detail but expensive and it took forever to get one (around 10 pm). There was no good place to sit and enjoy the atmosphere either as every single area was reserved for something or another. Instead, everyone stood smushed together in the bar area. Average experience and probably wouldn't go back

It's a TIKI BAR.

It's a tiki bar IN CHICAGO.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago WITH A SECRET ENTRANCE.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance IN A BACK ALLEY.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance in a back alley DECORATED BY SKULLS A PLENTY.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance in a back alley decorated by skulls a plenty WITH AWESOME CUTE AND UNPRETENTIOUS BARTENDERS.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance in a back alley decorated by skulls a plenty with awesome cute and unpretentious bartenders THAT MAKE FRESH STRONG AND DELICIOUS BEACHTAILS.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance in a back alley decorated by skulls a plenty with awesome cute and unpretentious bartenders that make fresh strong and delicious beachtails IN KITSCHY AWESOME CUPS.

It's a tiki bar in Chicago with a secret entrance in a back alley decorated by skulls a plenty with awesome cute and unpretentious bartenders that make fresh strong and delicious beachtails in kitschy awesome cups. SOLD.

pics.caption: Tropical Itch & Poipu Beach Boogie Board Cocktails

review.des: Strong, fruity drinks in giant, tropical mugs. What else could you ask for? It's a little pricey, but 1-2 drinks is all you need. Get there early to get a table. It's hard to stand and drink those big beverages.

Great spot for meeting girl friends for drinks or a date night. Theme and decor are done well. The drinks are served in large glasses that could be hard to hold, so I would get there early to get a seat at the bar or reserve a table.

I love the novelty of this place, and the ambience is great too. That said, I'm not big on sweet drinks so I don't tend to stay long here.

The bartenders are hit or miss - some are super friendly (and willing to sub in mezcal for those like me who don't love rum) and others are very by-the-book. This place is always busy so regardless, I give them credit for fast service and solid cocktails.

A fun place to take out-of-towners.

We made a reservation at the advice of yelp. We were there a Monday at 9:30 and it was busy but not crowded. I like the vibe of the place. Definite tiki bar. Drinks were really good! I can't remember the names but I'll post pics so you can match the glasses to the menu pics. They made all their drinks with care and the garnishes they put on them were so cute. Our waitress was really sweet and it was a nice chill spot to relax underground and pretend we were in the tropics. I'd come back again the next time I am in Chicago!

pics.caption: Something 109? Cute cup, drink was good on the fruity side
Yum! The one in the right was Limey and just the right amount of strong. The one of the left wasn't as good but loved thegarnish

review.des: Funky joint. Amazing food. Drinks, burgers, chips and Guac, fried chicken were all A+

Super fun bar! This was the last stop of the night and fortunately we had reservations because the line across the alley was long and it was cold outside. We were led down a dark staircase to this amazing underground bar. The music was techno meets island. The drinks were themed and tropical. It was really warm and crowded in there, which was the only downside. Good service and we were fortunate enough to have a reserved booth. I would definitely recommend this place for a fun night out!

This place is a hidden gem tucked away in an alley!

We came on a Friday night and it wasn't too packed. The music is your typical top 40 mixed with whatever the DJ liked. The bar was packed but there were a few empty tables. Luckily, we were seated within 10 minutes.  The thrifty thing about this place is you can get a table without having to buy a bottle.

They have some bar food too but we mainly came for the drinks. I ordered a painkiller (can't remember the number but it was the only one with mango). It was a little sweeter than anticipated so I had about a third of it then we left.

Overall, the decor was cute. There aren't many Hawaiian themed bars in the city so this was definitely a nice change of pace.

pics.caption: Shhh...it's a secret. Enter through the alley

review.des:
Three Dots and a Dash is a fun place to go for tiki bar style drinks. The entry is a bit hidden...it shares an address with a restaurant. To find the bar you'll need to go around to Hubbard and duck into a dark alley with a couple of bar employees, who will direct you down a set of stairs into the bar.

Three Dots and a Dash is an upscale tiki bar, very unlike the kitschy Hala Kahiki in River Grove. Which do I prefer? Hala Kahiki, since it has more of a cheap 50s "This is what I imagine Hawaii to be like" kind of vibe.

Three Dots and a dash has a respectable but not overwhelming menu of Tiki drinks, and they are strong, so watch out and give yourself some time to recover if you need to drive afterwards.

The drinks are completely covered with tiki fru-fru...the Dead Reckoning had the mandatory swizzle stick, a marigold flower, a stick with a lemon peel on it, a bunch of mint, a tiny umbrella and two straws...you get the idea.

The Dead Reckoning had a nice flavor, as did the Three Dots and a Dash, which had truly outstanding maraschino cherries...and I don't even like maraschino cherries.

Overall a fun place to go, worth a stop of you're downtown.

pics.caption: Three Dots and a Dash...delicious Hawaiian goodness.

review.des: This is my first time in Chicago and I found this place by word of mouth on the streets. I was hesitant to check it out - especially since you walk through an alley and into a dark staircase heading underground. That being said, I am so glad I checked it out! The place has a great ambience and the bar tenders are extremely knowledgeable as well as talented. My party and I had some of the tastiest cocktails of my life. My favorite place in Chicago so far!

Three Dots and a Dash does not fit in with what you'd expect in a Chicago bar...  But perhaps that's what makes this place so great.  Variety is the spice of life, right?  When you first walk in you'll enter a space filled with skulls...what did you get yourself into?  No worries, everything will be fine, this place is legit.

On to the important part, the fantastically innovative drinks.  All drinks come in a cute (or angry looking) tiki cup -- they will sell the cup to you if you decide you REALLY like it.  If you want to impress your lady date, get Bunny's Banana Daiquiri -- they seriously make a dolphin out of a banana, fins and all...impressive!  There can be a wait on weekends, so go early.  Great date spot for sure!

The cutest Tiki bar in Chicago! Not only are the drinks pretty (and photo worthy), they are delicious (and strong so beware)! The drinks can get a little pricey but are worth it because they don't skimp on the alcohol. The Piu Piu platter is a great shareable appetizer if you get a table and are going with friends. Just keep in mind this place gets really crowded!

Love this speak easy! The entrance is a little sketchy (right behind firecakes). The drinks here are super strong although a little heavy on the ice side. I had the Aloha Felicia and Surf Report. I enjoyed the refreshing cucumber in the Surf Report but definitely try the Aloha Felicia if you like coconut. I saw that some people ordered the huge "fish bowl" like drinks but i don't think its worth it. Its filled to the top with ice and it seemed like people were able to finish it pretty quickly. The bathroom is also very cleaned which is a plus in any bars.

I really like this place. The entrance is tucked away in an alley so it can be hard to spot from the street / be slightly janky feeling.

Inside is awesome though! Very on point tiki decor, awesome colorful lighting, and attentive staff. The ambience is very trendy, and somehow both kind of upscale and casual (think SoCal establishments). The drinks are all served themed drinkware such as ceramic-ware in the shape of a coconit and beautifully adorned. They are very strong though, so be warned!

Make sure to book a table for Thurs - Sundays since it's really popular and you might not get a seat otherwise.

Let's just get it out of the way first.  This place is pricey.  

But if you are in the mood for something different and want to get loopy in a kick-ass atmosphere... AND have the funds to go, DO IT.  This was my favorite bar that we visited in Chicago.  

The bar is in a back alley and is unmarked.  When you see the bouncer and a rope guarding a nondescript door, you're in the right place.  Once entering, you decend a stairwell to a basement Tiki heaven.  Everything i spot on... the lighting is cool, the music is perfect, the booths are comfortable and the servers are super nice.  

$65 will get you a LARGE zombie drink that is full of rum and is so damn good.  Split it with 4 and everyone's head will be spinning.  They have food too but we didn't try any.

This is my second time at three dots and I have to say I was disappointed this time around. I went in December of 2014 and I was beyond impressed with this place. They have gotten rid of certain things and it now feels more commercial. The menus are now different and basic. Some of the tiki cups aren't as cool and are bland (like an all white "tiki" cup). Overall the feel is the same but any smart business owner should know that cutting on the small details can hurt a business.

Yay! What a rockin' Friday night we had here! I knew Three Dots was going to be a success, because you can't go wrong with Lettuce. Tiki Bars are really hard to pull off and Lettuce has really hit this project out of the park! Everything from the decor, music, drinks, food and service was amazing.

We arrived around 8pm and the place was bustling already with happy campers sipping their boozy concoctions. The staff was super friendly and the hostess greeted us with a warm smile. We put our name on the list and only had to wait about 20 minutes which was amazing. We got a prime spot in the back right corner which was away from the crowds of people around the bar. Prime people watching.

The waitresses wear cute floor length floral dresses and I felt like I was on vacation instantly. We got some great recommendations from the staff who seemed to rave about their place of employment just as much as the visitors.

If you're coming here with a big appetite, that's a mistake because their menu is small only consisting of a small handful of little appetizers. We tried almost everything and were very impressed. The chicken skewers had great flavor with some yummy dipping sauces, we had the tuna crunch, crab rangoon, and the coconut shrimp to name a few.

The drink menu on the other hand is very large, filled with delicious island cocktails in silly little glasses. These drinks do take time to make, so don't get all impatient. Some of the highlights were the Painkiller, Mai Tai, and Bunny's Banana Daqueri, The drinks are very much worth their price as they are full of booze!

The part of the menu I enjoyed the most was the area "For Sharing". We saw several people sharing the Zombie Punch which serves 4-6 people for $75, it's served in a glass skull with several straws for group enjoyment. My friends figured they would go right to top and order the Treasure Chest for $395 which they say serves 10-12 people, but we had 5 and finished it in a decent amount of time. The presentation earns the stars as it's served in an actual wooden treasure chest with dry ice. The concoction has rum, passionfruit, pineapple, guava, lemon and lime served with a bottle of Dom. Let's just say we got the party stared right!

Hands down, check this place out. You're sure to enjoy!

pics.caption: Cute glasses. They're available for purchase as well.

review.des: The cocktails were incredible. Amazing modern update on a traditional tiki bar. Food was of good quality also. Service was attentive despite the bar being very busy. I would highly recommend

Great cocktails. Great ambience. Its a shady and dark place. I liked the music and the bartender was very sweet. There were no place to sit and stand too. Tables were full. So i had to finish my drink as fast as possible because it was So cold. If you will visit this place then make sure you dont fall on or spill your glass on someone or someone else wont fall on you.

What more can I ask!

Interested (in their customers, not the other bars staff) engaged, well pedigreed bar staff that know what they are talking about and love Tiki (as a note only 1/4 drinks I had was on menu).

They are more than happy to talk shop between slinging vodka sodas and long island ice teas for the clueless patrons, just don't be offended if the actual tiki drinks take a little more of their attention. Questions about Rum, (or Rhum, Ron, Cachacha etc), will be definitively answered, maybe even with a taste!

Even if you don't like Rum, they are very skilled in coming up with any cocktail to suit your profile (and very likely even a tiki drink).

Drinks flavors / profiles where well balanced, mind blowingly unique (in addition to the tiki standards), presentation is 5 stars the whole way, from proper ice and garnishes to nitro fog.

While the drinks are why you come, the food is pretty good as well, I had the short rib bowl, while it was a bit of a small portion, it represented and was a unique find.

Don't be put off by the alley entrance, its all good once your inside!
Once inside you will find the interior to be very classy, its conservative enough for business drinks and downtown crowds, but still just enough kitch enough for hardcore tiki fans.

The other patrons where generally nice, and (after a few) ready to make interesting conversation (without getting to "singles" bar), which is what you are looking for in a really great tiki bar, its hard to find the fine line between nice conversation bar and "pickup" bar but this place threads the line very well.

Note - I have been to "Lost Lake" as well (the other famous Chicago Tiki Bar), it was excellent as well, but if you are the typical tourist I would skip the adventure to the suburbs and stick with the Three Dots and a Dash for your Tiki drinks.

Personally planning to have multiple visits this trip, and will definitely be back (if I don't make a special trip just for this purpose).

I found the bar itself bit pretentious but the drinks are decent enough to make a visit worth while. Stepping past the bouncer at the door, and going downstairs to the basement, the vibe of the restaurant switched to odd mix of "club" and "Hawaiian. Resort". The intentionally vintage, full color, magazine-like menu, showcasing drinks, the history of the bar, and retail merchandise, handed to us by a inpatient server, was hard to read in the dark club-like atmosphere. With some deliberation, I decided on the Aloha Felicia: Rum, coconut, pineapple, and lime. Served with what appeared to be the entire basil plant as a garnish, the drink had pizzazz. It was like a fancy pina colada- creamy, refreshing and had bite from the basil at the same time. My drink was good and while the price tag was on the steeper end, I would have gladly paid for more, had the bar not been completely filled with reserved signs on the tables and bachelorette parties drinking out of massive group drinks with long straws.
In short, annoyed with atmosphere, but the drinks are good.
DANNY IS THE MAN AND THIS BAR IS AWESOME. Seriously, Danny was an amazing bartender and even more than that. An amazing host.

pics.caption: Cute dolphin! Danny showed us how to make one.

review.des:
A tiki bar in the heart of River North seems completely out of place and I love it! From the thatched roof above the bar to the festive tiki cups, it'll make you feel like you're in a tropical paradise, and fortunately not in a cheesy way. Then you notice the very random playlist throughout the night. We danced and sang along to some Next "Too Close" followed by Annie Lennox "Walking on Broken Glass". I guess hawaiian music would have just been too predictable. Fun is to be had here and unavoidable. A bit too much fun that is driven by the deceptively potent drinks (as shown by the floral scented sawdust camouflaging someone's "fun" all over the stairway as we stumbled out).

This is a good alternative for those that tire of the speakeasy trend, I imagine very long lines in the future. Seating is first come, first serve. If you're brave and want to swap spit with your friends, try one of the beautifully concocted sharing cocktails (Someone on yelp please get the $385 Treasure Chest and post a picture). Individual cocktails are $13 and you will feel every penny and then some the next morning.

I decided to try this place out last night. Sad to say I will not be returning. I thought this place was 21+? I had my sister's friend who was celebrating her 19th birthday come up & say hi to me with a drink in her hand. She also stated it was NOT her 1st time there. Sorry but I do not want to socialize & drink with underage girls in a downtown establishment.

If I could, I'd go with 3.5 stars - for me, Three Dots was "okay".

We made a reservation on Open Table (highly recommended, as they were having non-reso people stand even though there were open tables) and braved the recent hurricane like weather to get here. Be aware that the address on Yelp is somewhat misleading - the official address of 435 N Clark will get you to Bub's - a BBQ restaurant. To get to the bar, you have to go around the corner & through an alley. Fortunately, the host took mercy on us and let us in through a back staircase since we were already soaked through.

The interior is very nice - some booths along the back wall, a few tables and a thatched bar. It's clean, cool and to me, felt a bit sterile/corporate in comparison to other tiki places I've been. The menu has a good selection of cocktails - all individual drinks are $13 which isn't terrible for a craft cocktail in River North. I do wish the menu listed a bit more than just ingredients - basically, many of the drinks have the same/similar elements, so it's hard to pick. Fortunately, our server helped us out with some descriptions of what things actually tasted like.

Presentation? Absolutely gorgeous! I went with a Boogie Board something or other and it was fruity, not too sweet and fairly boozy which is pretty much what I was looking for. The garnishes are lovely (tropical flowers, pineapple slices) and not too over the top.

Our server was nice and helpful with recommends, but I think I'd probably ask to sit at the bar the next time around as I think it would be fun to watch drinks being made. Overall, I absolutely liked TDD and would come back - but I think there are better tiki options out there.

(Side note, and somewhat tangential: because of the downpour, TDD's bathrooms were flooded so they were sending people to the Bub's restrooms. Ladies, if you happen to use the Bub's WC - expect a surprise!)

I love walking into this place. Side door in the alley leading to this underground tiki lounge? Yes please! The food menu does not carry a variety of items but hey it's a bar. Me? I don't drink but I heard about this place from someone who I ranted to about how there aren't pretty non alcoholic drinks out there. Pretty alright. Nice tiki glasses and mugs.

Me and my friend got the The Captain's Pu Pu Platter that feeds 3-4! Yeah when we gets together, we eat. The pork buns and spring rolls were my fav. Coconut fried shrimp are included in the platter. I'm allergic to coconut and according to their menu, they're able to accommodate food allergies. Accommodate alright. The waitress made it seemed like it was a problem to have them cook the coconut shrimp separately and put it on a different plate. She got the manager who didn't even know if they cook with artificial or fresh coconut. Finally, they were able to fry the shrimp in a different burner aside from the rest of the platter items. I just don't understand why it was such a big deal if they say they can accommodate people with food allergies.

Besides that tid bit, everything was great.

I retract one star for the food. My friend and I came here totally starving and were disappointed by the small menu, although it looks like they've added to it since we went in. For drinks, I got a banana daiquiri and it came with an adorable banana dolphin. The drink itself was delicious. I also got their namesake drink that came in an adorable coconut cup that I ended up buying two of to bring home. The drink itself was also very tasty.

So disappointing! Called ahead for a reservation- was told it was a slow night- easy to get a table no res needed.  Arrived 10 minutes later- snobby hostess said there would be a 45 minute wait with 2 tables sitting empty! Apparently we didn't look hip enough!  Save the hassle- hit Bottlefork nearby instead! Never post negative feedback - sorry!

If you are in Chicago, you need to stop by! The only tiki bar in the city. It is a fast walk from the loop. It is located in a secret back alley with lots of awesome skulls. It's smart to book a reservation in advance. If you don't, it's a 15-20 min wait. The drinks are around $13, but are definitely worth it. I loved the Bunny's Banana Daiquiri and the Painkiller 639. To be honest, all of the drinks are great regardless of which one you get. I would love to come here with a large crowd to order the treasure chest or zombie punch. The bartenders and drinks are all good! Will definitely be back! I will try out Lost Lake as well though.

This place was fun to visit and experience. I had a hard time finding it but found that it was worth the time I spend wandering around. The drinks are colorful and taste great but cost more than I would typically be comfortable spending. Great for a night out to celebrate something with friends.

I have been to Three Dots probably a dozen times over the past few years. When I first started going, it was under different management and was just an outstanding place to get a novel cocktail. There was one night I arrived about 30 minutes ahead of my group and sat at the bar waiting. During that time I struck up a conversation with one of the bartenders about all of the 100+ types of rum they stock. He knew his stuff and even poured a few samples free of charge while explaining the different flavor profiles.

Their menu cocktails are fun and innovative, but definitely strong. More than two of these and you're in for a slow start the next day.

Despite my previous great experiences here, I think the bar has gone downhill since the management change. The last time we went, there was a DJ playing house music.
