You can get the tiki cups as a souvenir for 15 dollars a pop. We asked about the punch bowl skull and that was 200 dollars, if you guys were wondering.

:)

Tiki Bar? LOVE! The decor was amazing. As was the tropical tunes with a modern twist. Very cool.

The drinks? Ehh. Handcrafted, which is impressive and appreciated, but just so so. My group of 4 all tried different drinks, one of which we dubbed as 'Gasoline'. Ick.

Come prepared to wait - in line to get in. And then in line again to get drinks.

Don't understand the hype.  Expensive beverages come in grandma-style ceramic glasses shaped like pineapples and don't contain much liquor.  It's interesting... To try.... One time.  And then never again.  

If tiki is your thing then apparently this has a strong showing compared to others- I just thought it was too brash in terms of volume and overbearing decor.  To me I suppose the only way tiki can avoid tacky is to translocate to a beach.
Absolutely amazing concept and crazy yum cocktails! So so impressed by the decor and the vibe of this place!
Seriously felt as thought I was on south beach until I realized there was a roof. Drinks are pricey but worth the experience. I would go during the day to avoid crowds and doorman discretion issues.

If you like to wait forever for drinks then this place is for you! First my group and I waited 15 mins to get in which was whatever but then when we got inside it took 20 mins to even finally order our drinks and while waiting everyone was talking about how long they themselves were waiting and when I finally ordered drinks it still took about 15-20mins for me to even get it! When I drank it the bartender had made it way to strong and it was supposed to be a sweet drink, in the end I just would not go back!

This place is hard to find, but if u can it is pretty fun. The entrance is located in the alley behind xoco. Great ambiance, as you walk in you go down a hallway, then down some stairs and there is a big wall of skulls almost like you're entering some tomb. Once inside the restaurant it is a cool Polynesian theme. The drinks are great tropical concoctions with bananas shaped like dolphins, and flowers in everything (most drinks $13). the food menu is very brief, but most of it looked good. We went with the coconut shrimp ($14) and it was pretty good. It came with 4 sauces for dipping and 6 good sized shrimp. The place isn't cheap, but it is a pretty cool themed restaurant/bar.

pics.caption: Lots of garnishes in the drinks

review.des: Fun Polynesian themed bar, good for happy hour.  Drinks are strong so be careful!  Hard to find but really cute, walk down an alley go underground.  Make reservations to guarantee a table as it gets quite crowded.

This place is great! We went here because of the sort of speakeasy vibe and that they were going to be at the Punch Kings competition we were attending the following eve.
We sat at the bar and we definitely beat a couple waves of crazy busy. Sitting at the bar is often my favorite place. I love chatting with the bartenders and hearing people order.
I'd never been to a tiki bar, much less had much knowledge of tiki cocktails. My husband and I started off with two of the painkillers though while the ingredients sounded similar, they tasted very different and delicious.
I'm not going to lie, I saw the dead reckoning glass and ordered it based on that. It too was so good.
Now despite our being used to drinking at altitude, these drinks were starting to leave their mark so we ordered the thai fried chicken and the pork belly buns. SO good and helped a bit with the alcohol absorption.
Our bartender Danny took great care of us. In fact after watching these bartenders make these drinks of a hundreds ingredients and decor alike, I asked if they ever hoped for someone to order just a vodka tonic. Well those orders did come in from the basic bs of course and I felt so badly for these bartenders pouring these boring drinks into these crazy festive glasses. Why indeed would you go to a tiki bar and order a coors light or a vodka tonic? They actually had a great beer list, but whatever.
We loved this place!

Strong drinks and fun vibe. This place was suggested to us as out of towners, and admittedly, I was hesitant about the kitschy 70s-esque tiki theme, but it oddly works. I had the Jet Pilot cocktail, and how can you not? When your bartender pours you a glass of water with your drink and there's a skull on the menu next to it warning you to "sip delicately,"you know you're in for a treat.

Our bartender/mixologist did an excellent job with presentation and taste despite being slammed with orders on a Saturday night. My drink was garnished with pineapple leaves, fresh skewered orange rind, a marigold and cinnamon stick. One drink was definitely plenty!

Wow! What a place! Wheat else can I say? LEYE has done it again! The drinks are so unique and delicious as well as the ware they come in, the food made us want more and more, and the presentation and décor was very classy!

My girlfriend and I followed the advise of most Yelpers and made sure to be there when the opened, had no problem getting a seat, but they do fill up quick! Service is speedy because of the.

Although there are not many Tiki bars left in the city, I feel Three Dots and a Dash is the best in the city. I've had many bad experiences with other Hawaiian-Polynesian themed bars in the Chicagoland area making very very very weak drinks.  I mean so weak that I won't even get buzzed off of 3 Zombies! Not the case here!

Expensive? Yes. However, it was a special occasion for us and we went all out and had no regrets. Hopefully we can be back at it again soon! Thanks guys!

pics.caption: Me enjoying the Thai Fried Chicken and Luau Chips. The dips are amazing,  washing all that down with some Zombie Punch too!  ^_^

review.des: Very disappointed. Came at 1:50 am on Saturday. They're supposed to be open until 3 am, but when we [had to wait until people left] to get in, the guy immediately said "we're done for the day". All we wanted was one drink.  We were disappointed to see that they don't stick to what they promise. Especially since this place was recommended by multiple locals. Won't ever return to these people who think they are better than everyone else. I'm from LA and something like this would have been totally unacceptable.

This review is straight out of my second wonderful experience at this establishment.

After you get over feeling really cool about entering a bar via the building's back-alley entrance, this place has an amazing ability to transport you to an entirely different world.

The entryway to this basement tiki bar is adorned with skulls in the best possible way, and once you get past the host stand into the main room, the bar is adorned with a grass skirt. The lighting inside is minimalistic, and adds to the overall mystery vibe of the bar.

Once you've moved onto the menu, you'll learn that the classic cocktails are $13, but believe me they are so worth it. I've tried the "Painkiller No. 3," and the "Jet Pilot", both of which have been very strong, and very delicious.

(You'll also learn that three dots and a dash are morse code for the letter "V," which is what militaries listened for in World War II to signify VICTORY!)

Although I've never partook in the bar fare, a trusted friend has told me it's on the small side for the price. Another thing I haven't tried but am dying to is the "Zombie Punch" which features a punch bowl teeming with fog, courtesy of dry ice, and at $65 is designed to get 3-4 people decently on their way to a drunken evening.

Bottom line: go here, but a few drinks (served in awesome ceramic ware), enjoy the atmosphere, and if you need a true escape when the bitter Chicago winter comes... Hit up Three Dots and a Dash

Until I'm finally able to scrape together all the shit that I need to make my basement into a tiki bar, I'll be hitting Three Dots and a Dash.  Even then, I'd probably still come because I can apply the massive amounts of drinks I suck down in about five seconds to my LEYE card.  More points for me!

From the entrance off the haunted alley to the skulls on the way down the stairs to all the little details, I was charmed by the decor.  Even better were the drinks.  We tried a few including the banana daiquiri (featuring banana dolphin garnish) and each one was delicious.  I too dream of the $400 chest-o-booze and the slightly more affordable shell full of liquor.  I either need to come with a group or commit to getting insanely trashed so I can order the shell.  Also, they have the good cherries here.

We didn't try the food because we were going to dinner, but everything I spied on other tables looked and smelled good.  Get here early to avoid a line.
Overpriced. My ribs were charcoal and they make the drinks extremely strong, not necessarily pleasant to drink.

I've been wanting to come to this hyped up bar for a very, VERY long time...and I wasn't disappointed. Three Dots and a Dash definitely has the air of mystery around it when you walk up to the door, but once you're in the bar, it's just a fun eclectic experience. The drinks are definitely strong, so I wouldn't recommend coming here on an empty stomach. The bar can get a little packed, so be prepared to squeeze your way through the young professionals with your fruity drink. If you have friends visiting from out of town, I would absolutely recommend bringing them to this spot as it's a fun way to kick off the evening.

Upon hearing about Three Dots and a Dash, I was intrigued because I was told of the Hawaiian decor that this bar has, and that automatically drew me in because I've been to Hawaii and I loved it there. I was really hoping that their drinks would live up to the hype of the decor, and the drinks lived up to the hype, and then some.

To begin, Three Dots and a Dash can be hard to find. Even though the address is 435 Clark St., Bub City is actually located at that address. So, what you have to do is head down Hubbard street until you get to the alley, turn left, and there's a bouncer standing right at the first entrance that you come to. Once you get inside, you are in for some of the best rum-inspired drinks you will ever have.

I am warning you now, once you look at the drink menu, there are drinks that have skulls by them. The skulls mean that those drinks are stronger than the ones that do not have skulls by them, and they're aren't lying because the skull drinks are potent.

I began with the "Jet Pilot" which consisted of three different rums, cinnamon, grapefruit, and other ingredients, and this drink is potent. Even though it was potent, it had a certain smoothness to it, which I really liked. Next, I had the Painkiller No. 3, which had two rums, a coconut liqueur, and passion fruit. This drink sounds like a very sweet drink, but it really was not as sweet as I thought it would be, and it was really good. Finally, I had the Poipu Beach Boogie Board, which had a whiskey-rum combo, among other ingredients. The whiskey-rum combination alone tells you that this drink is serious, and it was seriously good. I will be returning to Three Dots and a Dash.

Before I leave this review, I have to comment on some of the people on here who have left negative comments regarding Three Dots and a Dash, and they need to be addressed. If the following offends people in any way, and/or they come off as arrogant, please be advised that I really don't care because this is my review and I can say whatever I want, so here we go. The truth needs to be told here.

If you don't like the drinks at a certain bar, then that's respectable. However, there are certain comments that just make no sense and defy logic. For instance, when people (as some on here have done about Three Dots and a Dash) complain about a two hour wait, that's just a dumb comment. Why? Any bar/lounge that is really good is GOING to have a two hour wait on a Friday and a Saturday night. What makes you think that you are going to walk into a hot nightspot and not have to wait? You should be concerned if you walk into a Friday/Saturday nightspot and you DON'T have to wait at all because the place is empty.

Another personal favorite comment of mine is when we got there, the bar was crowded and we couldn't get anywhere near it. Guess what? That's what happens when you go on a Saturday night! When I read these comments, I really shake my head because many people lack this thing called common sense. I shouldn't have to say what I am about to say in the following paragraph, but I guess I have to educate the slow people when it comes to nightlife.

Like I have always tried to tell people, you should really avoid going to any bar on Friday and Saturday nights because of the potential long lines outside as well as the crowded atmosphere. If you want a good experience, go Sunday through Thursday. However, if you must tempt fate and go on a Friday or Saturday, then get there early, preferably when it opens. Don't go at midnight because, again, it's going to be crowded. Even when it comes to Sunday, get there when it opens. We got to Three Dots and a Dash at 5:10 PM on a Sunday, and the bar was already crowded.

I've been to many bars and restaurants all over this country, and the aforementioned rules apply ALL ACROSS THE COUNTRY. So, before you complain, at least learn the rules. Again, if you don't like the drinks and Three Dots and a Dash, that's respectable. However, if you complain about it being crowded, then your comments are pointless.

With all of that said, go to Three Dots and a Dash. You will love it.
Although we had a reservation we had people standing all over our table. It took 10 minutes for someone to ask us what we wanted to start off with. However the atmosphere was really nice and vibrant.

I admit it's very cool to go to a tiki bar, the inside decor is really cool, and the drinks werent bad, however the line to get in can get super long, and the drinks are pretty expensive, most are like $13, or you can get shared drinks for like 30-40 dollars, while i had a good time here, i def couldnt afford to go here regularly

Other than the decor, this place is ridiculously over-priced and a waste of time. I feel bad for the bartenders who slave over time consuming tiki-style cocktails and probably receive meager tips from tourists or people stopping in for one or two before heading somewhere else. Even a well/rail vodka tonic will set you back $10. I can't imagine who would spend an entire evening blowing their money here. IMHO.

A friend and I had been hearing great things about this place and were excited to finally try it out.  We were less than impressed.

First of all, we waited in line for over an hour.  We got there at 9:30!  I recognize that this is River North and to somewhat be expected for a Saturday night.  However, when we called earlier in the day, we were assured that at that time, there would likely be a very short wait, if any at all.  We became increasingly frustrated when we saw approximately 30 people leave an no one was admitted after their absence.  

Once inside, we waited 15 minutes for the coat check.  The coat check workers managed to lose a coat.  Coat owner had to enter the room to investigate himself, while the line snaked its way through the bar.  Strike two.

Fast-forward to getting to the bar...another 45 minutes to get a drink!  We were passed over several times, as those seated at the bar were given first priority.  The drinks were complicated and there were far too few bartenders for the complicated concoctions.  We ordered two each right away, knowing we'd have to wait just as long for a second round.

On the upside, the atmosphere was very fun and the DJ was great.  The drinks were strong, which is always a plus.

All in all, not overly impressed.  The only way we would go back is if we had reserved a table in advance.

Ever done shrooms in Hawaii? If you have, flashbacks to that trip may surface upon entering Three Dots. Their freaky tiki theme is a little bit Jimmy Buffet and a little bit Marilyn Manson ironically placed in a back alley of the most bustling club neighborhood in Chicago.

The place is as laid back as a Lettuce venue can get for only being open a week or so. If you go during prime time there's definitely gonna be a line...for awhile. Once you get to the front of it though there's no cover and seating is first come first serve, which can be both good and bad depending on your spot swooping skills.

Drinks are pretty intricate so the bar line will also be backed up, but if you're willing to wait for food and beverage you know you're going to be getting quality. Lettuce Entertain You rarely disappoints.

Overall its something different and they do it pretty fantastically as you'd expect. If you don't mind battling all the scenesters for a few mai tais and some coconut shrimp it's definitely worth checking out.

Very cool spot.

Hidden in a back alley. Had Tiki cocktails during sub-zero weather here. Friendly service.

Just what you would expect from a Tiki bar, amazingly strong and tasty drinks in exceptional glasses. The atmosphere was ideal. We appreciated the detail of the ceiling mounted accent lights over each table, not so much to take away from the atmosphere, but perfect to keep the food and drinks highlighted. The Polynesian Pearl Diver and The Painkiller are natural choices for drinks and neither disappoints.

The food isn't exceptional but it is what you would expect and it is good. Similar to Gilt you come here for the drinks and not really the food. I would recommend the PuPu platter as it gives a reasonable selection at a respectable price. The shrimp and thai chicken were solid but the spring rolls were certainly a miss.

I haven't found a pub/bar in Chicago that really does excellent drinks *and* excellent food. Liberty Tavern in Arlington, Virginia did however, if you head east. If you have found one in Chicago - let me know!

Compared to others, I would recommend Three Dots over other peers such as Gilt most days of the week. Fun atmosphere, better service, and excellent drinks.

Fun place with a tropical theme. It is pretty touristy and gets crowded on the weekends. A reservation is definitely suggested if you want to sit. However, if you're looking for a colorful  coconut turned cocktail, you can't go wrong here.

Getting here was no easy task for me. My date and I stumbled upon two bouncers at Mother Hubbard's who looked like they could point us in the direction of Three Dots and a Dash. They told us to look across the street at the neon blue strip that was illuminating an alleyway. When we got to said alleyway, we were thankfully led by a friendly doorman to a flight of stairs going down....

To a tiki bar??? Why didn't anyone tell me that I was about to transported to what felt like a midwestern luau in a Chicago winter?

Just kidding. I obviously knew what I was getting myself into as I sped down Lake Shore Drive in a Jaguar. I knew full well that with a little help from Yelp, I had just found a truly unique date spot for the night.

So, we get to the bar, order some tropical drinks, get seated at a table in the back that over looks the entire room.
It's not a very big venue, so I'm not saying much.

As my date tried to put his tongue down my ear, I attempted to read the tiny menu that had like 5 items on it. So of course I order all five items...
I had a funny moment when I asked the waitress if the tuna appetizer was sashimi or tartare'd. She said it would be prepared sashimi-style. But when it came out, it was cut up into a tartare.
Um, what? This is what I wanted but you said it wasn't like that missy.

Overall I had an ok time at this place. If I'm ever in the mood to pretend I'm on Waikiki beach, I'll be coming around to this quirky establishment for sure.

UPDATE:
I received a personal note from someone that works here and they've informed me that their team will be given better instructions on how to present the menu items. The fact that a member of management took the time to do that really took me by surprise. This place really cares about its reputation and the impression it leaves on its guests. Not only will I tell my friends about Three Dots and Dash, but I most certainly will be back.
Went here for my birthday got lost trying to find the place but once we found it the place was beautiful Everyone was nice me and my bestfriend enjoyed ourself must go again

I love that there is a tiki bar in Chicago. I think it's ironic and cute and everything else. I could see how it could be the best in the country. But my visit yields three stars.

The decor, drinks, mugs that the drinks come in, the fact that it's in an ally and underground, the concept of tiki in the windy and cold city of Chicago should land this place an easy 4 star rating. The problem I had with it was simply how slow everything was.

It wasn't as crowded as I would've imagined, yet there was still a 10 person line outside. Once inside getting to the bar was easy enough, but getting a drink order to the bartender was like trying to get MJ's autograph (mandatory, lazy Chicago reference). Once the order was placed (order two at a time), it took the bartenders full concentration to mix 3 of the 174 rums they seem to have (everything has rum in it) with decorative fruit and excessive ice. Those drinks were damn good and damn strong though.

I think table service is the way to go. Plan ahead. I hear the food is pretty good too.

So it's slow, even on a slow day, but it's worth the 2 hours and 15$ drink to see. Underwhelmed, but satisfied.
It's very hard to find the entrance but when you are inside looks like wonderland. Great great cocktail I suggest to do the reservation at least 2 weeks in advance.

Loved the ambiance. Drinks were strong and reasonably priced. Service was good. Best way to end our last night before heading back to Cali. Best bar my folks and I have encountered since we've been here.

And, with all do respect, I must add that our waitress Brittany was the most gorgeous girl up in Chi-town who offered great service.

This place is a must!

pics.caption: Cali to Chi-town! Thanks to Brittany for capturing this photo for us.
Port of Calls ain't no joke. The drink's straight up and that giant ice cube that comes with it is a trip.

review.des: Wish we would have made reservations for a table! The place was great for a drink but because they are pricey and a little time consuming to make I would recommend making this an early stop on a night out if you don't have a reservation.

Tiki Bar located in a creepy back alley of N Clark and W Illinois St. This place is tough to spot for newcomers like myself! If it weren't for the bright neon lights at the door and the huge line of people eager to go in, I would've missed it!

The place is famous for inventive cocktails served in funky goblets and tall glasses. Most cocktails are rum based, add additional hard liquors to spice it up, and a tropical fruit juice (pineapple was the one I recall the most).

I ordered a cocktail called Dead Reckoning, served in a tall tiki glass with a skull, and honestly expected more of it. The drink was probably designed to get people wasted, more than to enjoy its flavor. We had a few different cocktails at my table and all drinks personally gave me that same impression.

The food was pretty good though! I had coconut shrimp, which were ok, and some Thai fried chicken, which were awesome!

Overall, the place offers inventive cocktails, finger food, a casual atmosphere, friendly staff and long lines given its current popularity.

Please don't go here. I like it and I don't want it to be too crowded next time I go!

Most drinks (creative cocktails) are $13, and some are very strong! Aside from the fun menu of crazy cocktails, they have a small selection of beer and wine. They also have a short menu of appetizer-style food.

Entry is off the alley off Hubbard, parallel to Clark street. You may need to stand in line, and the doorman may require everyone - even those who look well over 21 - to show an ID. You enter the place down a flight of stairs, but a sign on the wall indicates that there's a wheelchair-accessible entrance somewhere nearby. The place is dark, the music is retro, and the waitresses all wear flowered dresses. It's just adorable.

It lives up to being a Tiki bar. There's no question about that. The theme is fantastic. All of the drinks are great. The food is better than average bar food, but nothing special. I have 3 issues with Three Dots:

1. Not enough bartenders. Making a drink is like making a meal. It takes time. Nothing wrong with that. But, you can't have 2 - 3 bartenders for as many customers they have inside.

2. Look, if you pay $350+ for the treasure chest (which we did), you had better damn well be able to keep the chest. Major let down.

3. The outside staff and the back alley entrance come across really douche-y. Guys, it's a tiki bar, velvet ropes should not be needed.

This is a place to take friends from out of town to wow them or to check out once a quarter. It's just not a regular place for me.

Meh. That's how I felt about this place.

I was with some good friends so we're gonna have a great time no matter what, but this was our last stop of the night and I was not impressed by the service.

Seems like an older crowd hangs here, as its a more sophisticated type of draw I guess, but I just can't get down with Tiki bars unless they are on the beach. The music was blah, and the waitress took forever. I had to go track down a manager just to get our check and it wasn't even busy.

The drinks were pretty good, and I'm glad my friend was generous enough to take me here as I am not from Chicago, but I don't think either him or I would go back here as it wasn't our decision to begin with.

Favorite bar in River North. Awesome drink menu (liked it more before they updated it) and a great atmosphere. Great place to go and escape the weather for a while. The food, while limited, is also really well done. The special souvenir glasses each drink is served in, and that you can take home for a price, is a nice touch as well.

I love me some tiki drinks! They no longer offer the Paul McGee drink menu, which is what made three dots famous in the first place, so if you want some of his original concoctions you will have to go to Lost Lake. That said, they brought LA transplant Julian Cox on as head bartender/mixologist, but I can't speak to the quality of his menu since I haven't been back since the latest menu change. To be perfectly honest, based on what I've heard about some of the changes (to the menu and the general vibe) I'm not sure how pleased I will be when I do head back. I'm very dedicated to the classic mid-century heritage of tiki bars, and I've heard the music has changed & the prices have gone up (Yikes!). I'm sure I'll stop in again at some point, because this place is still a little bit magical and the drinks are strong.

...-

After dinner, my friends asked our waiter for suggestions on lounges/bars. Cut to us walking in an empty back alley and down a flight of stairs lined with skulls on the side.

Three Dots and a Dash (morse code for the letter "V") is a tiki bar. When I picture tiki bars I think cheesy, but this place was far from that. It was modern and laid back.

It was a Sunday night, so we easily got a booth. My friends had a hard time picking a drink because they wanted something that was going to come in a cool tiki mug. After the fact, we realized that they could've just ordered a drink they wanted and requested for a specific mug. And no, you don't get to keep the mugs afterwards, but they can be purchased separately.

The most notable drink on the menu is the "Treasure Chest No. 1", which comes in an actual treasure chest served with a bottle of Dom Perignon ($385 serves 6-8).  There are also drinks served in seashells or a skull that is meant for sharing.

Overall, it's a great place to gather a group of friends to share a drink with, or a place to stop in before continuing on to your next stop of the night!

The best Caribbean themed bar with awe inspiring cocktails and a cozy ambience. I just love the luau chips and Thai fried chicken in chilly garlic sauce.

This place rocks!

Such a chill spot. Drinks are super strong and come in cool Tiki themed cups. Food is okay but it is very over priced. Both times I have gone, it's been packed and they've both been weeknights.You don't need a reservation if you just want to hang out at a bar but if you want to sit down at a table make sure you call ahead of time.

One of the coolest bars I've ever been to. Wait was kinda crazy, and once we got in, we had no place to really sit or stand, but drinks were really tasty and the atmosphere was dope on a rope. Also checked out the other tiki bar in town, something about a lake that got lost, but this place was much better in my opinion in terms of atmosphere (although we didn't have to stand at Lost Lake.) Definitely recommend this spot when in Chicago.

One of Chicago's newer hot spots from one of the best bartenders in town. The first thing you'll notice is this place has no signs and it's down an alleyway in the basement of a building. I don't know about you, but that makes it cooler in my mind.  As you may have figured out by now, this is a tiki bar that serves more tropical drinks. The decor is pretty nice and the atmosphere, like most tiki bars, is pretty fun.

I had the Pago Pago, Jet Pilot, and Painkiller. All drinks were bigger and stronger than they appear, that's for sure. The bartender I had was really cool (forgot his name) and very helpful. Definitely one of the better bartenders I've had in town. I thought all the drinks were good, though I thought the Painkiller missed the mark on what it can be. To clarify, I've had Painkillers in a few different Caribbean nations, including the spot in which it was invented in the British Virgin Islands. I know I'm going to sound weird here, but they should get a bottle of Pusser's Rum (yes that's really the name) from BVI and experiment with that. The one here isn't nearly as good, but it's still a solid drink nonetheless, just not as good as it could be.

This place is definitely good and I can't wait to try more of their cocktails and food.

This place is insane in the membrane good! I first fell in love with tiki-style places as a kid going to Mai Tai ... then in San Francisco I went to the Tonga Room, and I hoped, wished, and dreamed that a tiki lounge would make its way to chilly Chicago and it did!

Cocktails
All of the cocktails take time to make and are very complicated - think Violet Hour or Aviary.  It's nicely decorated and everything has some Tiki vibe, down to the straws.  Service was great, we sat at the bar and waited for our table for 40 minutes.  The place was jam packed, but there was ample space at the bar to order a drink.

Mai Tai: So Strong it took me 20 minutes to drink that bad boy
Three Dots And A Dash: Signature cocktail, but a bit too fruity for my taste
Poipu Beach Boogie Board: Did someone punch me in the face with love? because I am obsessed with this drink!  
Painkiller No. 3: All I tasted was pineapple... and my legs going numb...
Tall As A Tree And Twice As Shady:  Total man whisky drink, I was not a fan.

Food
We ordered the Luau chips and guacamole, fried chicken, and coconut shrimp.  There were four dipping sauces - spicy, mustard, peanut, and mango glaze.  The Fried Chicken was the best thing I've eaten in a while.  Order it!

We had five drinks, three small plates, bill was $110.  Kind of steep, but the drinks are worth the $13 and because they are fruity you slurp them up quickly.  I suggest going there for happy hour or during the week because they are going to be bumping with buzz for a while.  **They do have Opentable!

pics.caption: Mai Tai and Beach Boogie Board

review.des:
Finding this place just a few days after it opened, while on lollacation in Chicago and just across the street from our hotel was the highlight of the trip/dream come true.

Being a some what recent tiki enthusiast I've been hugely disappointed with the tiki bars in Los Angeles.

NOTHING comes close to Three Dots and a Dash.  1/2 the menu are classic's and even subtle twists that improve upon their perfection.  The other modern half is equally as awesome.

We tried over 1/2 the drinks on the menu in the two nights we visited, purchased several of their cool varied tiki mugs and got to meet Paul McGee.. THE MAN responsible for TDaaD's perfection.

The atmosphere/decor is A+++.  Down the alley past the tiki torches, down the stairs you see the wall of skulls, into the main room with classic and beautifully done tiki vision and impressive well stocked Rum selection.

The bartenders are fast, knowledgably and talented with the garnish. Not to mention pretty quick considering the complexity of the drinks they make.

Highlights include Bunny's Banana Daiquiri and the Dolphin or Octopus shaped banana garnish. OMG. So cute.  The Mai Tai is beyond perfection with their own twist using Macadamia Orgeat. The Pain Killer, Three dots and a dash, Zombie (punch), Jet Pilot, etc. etc. etc.  ALL THE BOMB.

The ambience is what makes Three Dots and a Dash a hit! Usually when you go to speakeasies, they have the typical dimmer lighting, whiskey cocktails, and quasi 1920's feel. Here, you descend a level surrounded by skulls and deep blue lights, listening to fun muffled music at the base of the stairs. You can then turn either right or left, the left side including a fun tiki bar with popular music and really fun island-inspired drinks! The tuna tartare is legit, though I wouldn't recommend Three Dots for dinner. It's a great happy hour, after-work, pre or post dinner hangout, and I've had the most fun here with a small group of girlfriends!

If you have out of town guests coming in, this is always a fun place to start the night at!

Yes, it's weirdly in an alley. Yes, it's weirdly underneath Bub City. Yes, it can be pricey. And yes, it feels slightly pretentious. But yes, I love this place.

The drinks are delicious... not many places offer a banana-frozen-something-or-other & Three Dots does theirs up right. I love coming here in the dead of winter, forgetting that it's -13 outside, and sipping on a tiki cocktail while relaxing island-themed music plays on the radio.

I love the mugs/glasses, the time & care they put into the cocktails & the presentation. Even the small bites are delicious. Definitely one of my favorite LEYE joints in the city.

Alright. Where do I start. Ummm. This is no Bob Chinns. Lets hold the Mahi Thais and the Hawaiian shirts and work on your drinks.
I am giving two stars because its a good concept. The cups are all interesting, but the drinks have way too many different combinations. Not a great taste.

The tiki ambiance and thoughtful cocktails make this place worth the price. I would also suggest getting there before 9 or after 11:30 if you're planning to go on a weekend, in order to avoid a long line.

I recommend Three Dots and a Dash to all my out of town friends staying in the downtown area. Besides a handful of other bars, downtown joints can pale in comparison to places in Lakeview and Wicker Park (IMHO), so as a Loop resident I love love love that I can claim Three Dots as semi-mine. When my guests enter the bar, or even when they see the trendy alley entrance, I get this undeserved sense of pride, like I somehow birthed it.

Anyway, the atmosphere, decor, and drinks are all on point. It's pretty much the same drink menu that you'll find at other tiki bars, but these are noticeably strong, and at around $14 you definitely get your money's worth. The bar maintains a high energy level with quiet a bit of density, yet I've never had a problem getting a drink order in.

Only advise - go with someone who won't mind taking shameless look-how-much-fun-we're-having, drink-in-hand selfies with you :)

One of Chicago's gems-cool speakeasy with an amazing menu of cocktails and appetizers. Extremely well themed-great for an occasion. Make a reservation because it's hard to get in. 4 out 5 because it is pricey.

I'm here to reiterate everything said in previous reviews. This is a great place to go for happy hour, especially if you are looking to get buzzed. Everyone will have a good time looking over the various drinks on the menu, all served in fabulous and unique tiki glasses and $13, and taste testing what everyone ordered around the table. While they don't have a large food menu, everything I have had there is delicious, especially the Thai Fried Chicken. However, if you want to have a little assistance in holding your liquor, I suggest ordering some food there or eating something before going (and if you don't care for Asian food be sure to eat elsewhere as the entire menu contains an Asian flare).

I keep coming back for girls' nights or happy hours because it is a great experience and all the drinks I've had are tasty and fun, and the atmosphere is fantastic for being located in a basement. Say aloha to Three Dots and a Dash next time you want to sip on a tiki cocktail!
Pricey but good drinks. The bartenders really know how to create an experience for their guests.

This place was amazing, such a cool tiki vibe without being cheesy.
The drinks are uber strong and a lot of work must go into them, so the $13 price tag isn't as steep as it first appears.
The food was also great, I got the thai fired chicken...phenomenal! It was spicy, but not overbearing and the portion size was bigger than I expected. My friend really enjoyed her coconut shrimp, and she got four different dipping sauces to try with it.
To enter, follow the blue lights into the alley off of Hubbard, it's nowhere near as sketchy as it sounds. Then you go down some stairs and a hostess will seat you, or, if they're busy, send you a text when your table is ready.

I'm only giving this place 2 stars for the decor and the coolness factor. The decor is great. Very unique and done well. I went late on Sunday. It was 1/4 full at best in the bar area. I asked to set in a booth (which were mainly empty) and was not even acknowledged. I was escorted to a small two seat table and told the booths were only for groups. But wait... there was  basically no one there?  Customer service: Strike One.   The drinks are sweet and expensive but come in cute tiki inspired containers so that's fine. We were rushed to order food by the waitress who acted as if we were annoying her for even being there. Tried to order the chips but she said they out. So we ordered the spring rolls which were horrible. The plate had two lines of sweet chili style sauce smeared on it. We asked the waitress for some other sauce or more of what was on the plate and she just pointed to the plate and said, "Its on the plate." Then hastily scurried away. Oh but I could see her back by the exit on her phone. NICE. We just left. If you think that service is important as I do and that it adds and/or compliments the overall experience, avoid this place at all cost. They just don;t care if your happy or not. They obviously have other places to be or people to text or tweet or something.

In Summary: DISAPPOINTING

RMM

This is a super cute tiki bar in Chicago. I did not expect this at all especially since the entrance is in a back alley. I loved the music and fun atmosphere. Drink prices are cheap and the service is great. I highly recommend!!

Was in Chicago for just a night helping a friend move, and man was this place a treat! Really cool menu and drinks. We had reservations which I highly recommend. If you want a unique experience to get a drink, I highly suggest coming here. Loved the tiki speakeasy vibe!!

Took a while to get our drinks and the punchbowls are a little over-priced, but the cocktails were good, so was music and ambiance. Liked the fact that they had plenty of seating, but ventilation could be better.

Amazing. This was the perfect first stop on our night out. We got a line jump for our group of ten and boy was that worth it. This place is unlike anything I've seen before. Funny and kitschy yet trendy and cool. The best vibe. We got two private tables- my only regret is that we weren't in the main room, but it really didn't matter we had a great time anyways. The drinks were a little too sugary, but that's to be expected. We tried half the menu including the flaming skull (which came in a pineapple) and enjoyed everything. I am totally obsessed with this place and will definitely be back!! service was ok, but the atmosphere and fun drinks was truly memorable. Plus the entrance wth skulls in a back alley is pretty hilarious. Can't say enough good things about this place!

This place is so beyond overrated. The decor, the atmosphere, and the overpriced cocktails are all just...bad. Truly do not understand the draw (unless you like mugs of pure sugar advertised as mai tais).

I was in town for a few days and wanted to find a place close to my hotel to meet my local friends. Three dots emerged as one of the better choices. When I reserved a table, I did not have the final RSVP numbers for the table, so my estimate ended up being wayyyy off. The hostess Gina was very flexible and accommodating given my error. The bar is not very large, which makes seating a fairly large group pretty challenging. Gina made sure we were well taken care of. We had a great section and it was comfortable. On top of that, the food was delicious and the drinks were wonderfully crafted (but a tad on the expensive side). We had a friendly server and my group enjoyed themselves. I will certainly be back. Thanks!!

One of my favorite spots...I've taken family & friends we always have a blast. The atmosphere is awesome, chill crowd, awesome location, and of course strong drinks!!

Ten thumbs up and all the stars!!

Really fun bar. It was Tiki themed and they played lots of 90s and early 2000 pop and R&B music, which was awesome. The drinks are made to order with lots of embellished garnishments. One of our drinks came with fire. I would argue, that the for sharing drink, zombie punch, does not serve up to 4, as there was a ton of ice. I also loved the real maraschino cherries that came with several of the drinks were great

pics.caption: Bunny's banana daiquiri, three dots and a dash

review.des: Great atmosphere! The tiki drinks have fresh ingredients with unique combinations. Walk through the darkened alley, down the stairwell and enter your island paradise.

pics.caption: Just some jet pilots drinking jet pilots

review.des: Was a cool place, but nothing all that special.  The drinks were good, and very alcoholic, but also very pricey.

Tasty, creative drinks and an outstanding staff!  It's hard to find (enter through the alley on Hubbard Street), but the reward is worth the hard work.  All the drinks are served in super kitschy, one-of-a-kind mugs that are also for sale.

Way cool, truly unique, literally underground tiki bar. Try the Saturn, it's with gin instead of rum... And it's GREAT!

I thought this place would be kitschy, but I was pleasantly surprised. It had a Hawaiian/Tiki look but it wasn't overwhelming and garish.

The menu is huge (literally and figuratively) and the drinks are strong. I don't know if anyone has ordered the huge liquor chest, but I like that punch bowls are coming back. Easy sharing with friends! I can't remember the names of the drinks we ordered, but they were all pretty strong and made with TLC.

Only some things that I wish were changed was maybe not so dim lighting? Hard to read the menu.

Lettuce take your money should be the name of who came up with this idea. VERY bad service is not really even the start and overpriced unimpressive drinks.

To start I had high hopes for this place as some people had told me how amazing it was. So when I walked down the stairway to the entry I was definitely starting off impressed. Let me assure you it did not last long.

I arrived in a party of 2 on a Monday night around 7pm and the place was pretty empty. There where MANY tables available through the entire time we where waiting for a table. I was told that there was nothing available when arriving and that we could put are names on a list. We never got a table the entire time we waited and drank which was about an hour. We where never asked if we wanted food which we did.

After been told we where on a list the fun began. So with normal expectation of a 15 min wait we walked over to the very full bar area even though there where 15-20 table seats empty and most of them stayed empty for the full hour we where there. I guess there thing is make people wait for seats. So we sat down and waited and waited and waited ..... So as we waited to order drinks I was informed that I was standing to close to the side of the bar and the server decided to move the rope so close to me I could hardly move with out falling over. So after almost getting my legs roped off and waiting 20 min for the bar tender Lisa to ignore us completely and serve even new arrivals to the bar with out even looking at us. After removing the rope from behind my legs and complaining that we had been waiting for not only a drink and a place to sit as we had not yet even been able to sit down. The manager did come over after the 30 min mark and give us an extra stool for the bar after I stopped another server and asked if there where actually reservations for the large number of empty seats on a Monday night. The manager did come over and asked if everything was ok. It wasn't until then that we where able to order a drink about 30 min after arriving. We then waited another 10 min to actually get are drinks. Are server still didn't ask if we wanted to order any food the whole hour we where there. I would say that I am not surprised to get bad service down town but I was definitely not impressed by anything about the bar, drinks, severed, staff or operations.

The drinks where overpriced and I have had better at other tiki bars. My opinion the whole bar is just a unauthentic gimmick to be able to charge crazy prices doe mixed drinks. For what you get in your cup I have been to a lot better locations and had a lot better frozen drinks. To top it all off the server took my drink before I even got to finish it and threw out at least 1:4 of my $16 mixed drink. If your looking to wait a long time for overpriced drinks and be completely underwhelmed then this is your place. I would suggest that you skip this place completely and just go down the street to Fado for a nice beer.

My kind of bar! Gets super busy but it was worth the wait. They really put some effort into making your drinks look good. I loved how thy played 90's Hip Hop all night. Some of the drinks were kind of weak and could have had more alcohol content but they made them so pretty that I couldn't be mad.

pics.caption: The banana daiquiri taste really good...would be better with more alcohol content

review.des: I was finally able to secure reservations for this place the day after Christmas. My reservation was for 7:30pm, I arrived 5 minutes after the scheduled time and was seated shortly afterwards. The atmosphere is really nice, dark and Asian themed. The service was great and the drink were good. There is a good variety of drinks the food not so much. Drinks are priced at $13 give or take and the presentation is great. Check it out but make a reservation or prepare to wait hours.

This place is unbelievable. The decor, the drinks, the music, the island vibes... all of it is fantastic. The service is friendly and the drinks are great. Awesome place and fun atmosphere to hang with friends. Feels like your not in the heart of downtown Chicago!

This place definitely has fun drinks and a fun tiki bar theme but you have to do a lot of waiting.  You first will probably wait outside in the alley for a while before even being let in.  Then you have to pretty much fight your way to the bar.  Because the drinks are so complex, it takes forever for the bar tenders to make.  I've gotten both the Mai Tai and Banana Daquiri and both were super boozy.

Overall, I feel like this place is just over rated and isn't quite worthy of all the hype.

Finding this place was terrible. When our cab driver said we were at our stop, my friend and I were confused. We were told it was in an alley so we went to the nearest alley (dark, wet, scary) and held on to each other. Oops, wrong alley! Look for BLUE LIGHTS!! We both had the Thai fried chicken, it was pretty good. The drinks were very cool too. Each drink came in a different cup. I had the painkiller no. 3 and my friend had the jet pilot. The place itself was super cool. We felt like we were on some island. Make a reservation! It gets packed.

Let me just say, brace yourselves for the first sip you take from your drink because it is going to be STRONG but delicious! Three Dots and A Dash is a legit representation of a tiki bar, the presentation of the drinks were cool, cute, and very tiki! Now, with that said, let me give you guys a tip: If you want to attend Three Dots & A Dash FRI-SAT make a reservation so you and your party get a table, me and my party made a mistake of not making one and ended up standing by the very crowded bar.

The drinks were 13 bucks each and they were definitely worth it. The atmosphere was great, the crowd was a mixture of ages, we got our drinks right away despite the bar being full. My only complaint is that the place should be a little bigger, but, other than that this place is very worth checking out! Can't wait to go back!
Love this place! Great drinks and a nice little escape from the Chicago hustle and bustle outside its doors! A hidden little gem that I plan to visit time and time again!

As someone who lived in the DR for 4 years, its so satisfying to know I can get Brugal and other island delights in the States. Great ambiance, not too loud, love the darkness and the way it looks like walking into a speak easy. Great food, different type of bar food, tropical and delicious. Def a tad pricey though. The cost of a drink with Brugal, cost more than the actual bottle does... food was a bit up there as well.
Looking for something different...This place is awesome. Novel, but awesome. Hawaii-tiki feel, with an underground (word-of-mouth) feel to it.

Loved the super lively vibe, ambience, awesome music/dj (on the loud side), option to dance, wide variety of drink options!!

Didnt like the long wait outside, that we had to seat ourselves and wait again for a table for a while, the high priced drinks.

Overall, would come again for a special wild occasion. Not your regular visit to a lounge type of place...

I went here on opening night with a group of friends. I've been to only 1 Tiki bar (Tonga Room in SF) and loved it, so when I walked in (and down, it's underground) here I was in awe. The place is decked out in sweet tiki decor! The top of the bar is lined with what looks like part of the roof of a hut and there are huge beautiful totem pole looking piece throughout.

The ambiance is dim and intimate but with a little of a spooky vibe, which is perfect. One thing I didn't like was the music. When we walked in they were playing some more ambiguous music, some unknown reggae-type stuff, etc. which was fine. But then they switched into mid-2000's hip-hop (think old Common, etc.) and it really completely destroyed the vibe. Some people nodded their heads, but I don't think that means it's the best option -- a fellow visitor agreed with me. I did however appreciate that it was loud enough I could hear it, to give the space some vibrance, however I could still talk to friends without shouting too much, which is important as this place is primarily a sit down place.

The music situation really put a damper on the vibe for me, and is the primary reason for the star off, though another reason was because the service was really slow, to the point that even if we wanted another round after it taking ~20 minutes to order and receive the first round, I would go for the check rather than another round. To be fair, this could just be a kink with it being opening night and all. Our waitress was extremely nice and even brought us all a round of water without us asking, so we definitely appreciated that.

The drinks are $13 each, great tasting and -very- strong as traditional Tiki drinks are! Half the menu is Tiki classics and half are modern twists on old Tiki cocktails. Part of the menu is also for large shareable drinks. All the drinks come served in very interesting looking glasses, many with scary type faces, some are porcelain coconuts, etc. And if you really love one, you can buy one from them -- a nice touch for the tourists! I had the Halekulani which was boozy yet smooth and a little creamy ... it was delicious. I also tried a friend's "Jet Pilot" which is marked with a skull on the menu to signify alcohol potency! It too was very good, with a slight bitter turn but it wasn't too intense.

I didn't get a good look at the food menu but it seemed small and inconsequential.

All in all, I loved this place and will be back very soon to try all the drinks. The decor and drinks are the star at this underground Tiki joint. If you're like me and don't want to hear Chris Brown while you try to soak in the "Tiki experience" then you'll likely want to head out after a drink, so make other plans.

pics.caption: 2 "Halekulanis", 2 "Death Pilots" and a "A Lonely Island In The Middle Of The Sea"

review.des:
Went here for drinks on a Thursday evening. Great ambiance, great drinks, and neat little twist in the middle of downtown Chicago.

It was quiet busy and we got lucky with getting bar seats -- you might not be so lucky, so be sure to make a reservation.

I'm not a guy who loves excessively crowded bars, so I wouldn't say that this is my kind of spot. If your scene is a "standing room only" situation and lots of rum, you'll immediately love this place.

Not my thing, but I hope everyone else enjoys.
Very strong and delicious drinks. I love the atmosphere. I am a vegetarian and their food for vegetarians is literally guacamole and chips, which is annoying. But great place for drinks.

Great if you have reservations. Staff is always friendly. Drinks are strong, you get your money's worth. Only negatives are it gets over crowded and people are constantly running into you. Wait list for reservations is very long.

This place is a ton of fun. The drinks and food are delicious. I've been here several times for happy hours with friends. It gets super busy really quickly so I recommend getting there right when they open. Be prepared for high prices -- this place has a great reputation across the US in the tiki bar scene so it draws a lot of people and press, hence the high prices. Not to worry, though -- the cocktails pack quite a punch, so you won't need many!

This is probably my fav place for drinks. Been here so many times. The wait is never long. The drinks are strong! So you don't need to buy multiple drinks. They can also many non alcoholic drinks!! I highly recommend checking out this place.

Coolest atmosphere ever. All Pacific decor, chintzy of course, but very well done. It's tucked away in an alley so a bit confusing to find, but it's awesome once you get in. Drinks are interesting, all too sweet for me. They point out the level of alcohol strength in each one, so that's convenient for light weights and drunkies that want their bang for their buck. All drinks come in different awesome glasses, most with an orchid or umbrella. The food menu is limited and the food itself isn't very good. Go early to avoid the crowds, it isn't very big.

My friend and I were visiting from NYC and this place was recommended by a colleague. We ordered the long walks and we felt they literally took 45 seconds to make. We ordered two and they were both perfection. Cassandra our bartender was the perfect balance of hospitality, precision and poise. All of the cocktails are extensive and she really delivered. Because of her we will return on our next visit to the Windy City.

... & - (see what I did there?) will always hold a special place in my heart, as it was the 1st bar I went to when I moved to Chicago. Three Dots and a Dash boasts a chill environment, super friendly staff, and drinks that are tasty and pack a punch. The place can be a bit hard to find since it's tucked away in an alley, but just look for the skulls and the neon blue lights.

I've only had the drinks here, so I can't comment on the food, but the dishes smell and look amazing. I'll definitely have to try some food the next time I'm here.

Definitely a great place to go!
I went for my chica's bachelorette party. Amazing time, delicious cocktails, great service. Will definitely be back!
Caribbean themed bar with a number of really good drinks. Fun atmosphere with a warm environment which makes you feel like you're in the Caribbean. Great date spot for a drink or two.

Finally made it here for work happy hour. Nothing really unique about this place. They mostly have drinks with a small appetizer menu. We got the dip and crab Rangoon. Like the waitress warned us, it's mostly just there to soak up the alcohol. Neither dish was that great.

The drinks were quite tasty. They are all $13 each and you get what you pay for. They actually seemed like a decent deal. I just got 1. Smart decision as they are very strong and delicious.

I would come back. But I would make sure to eat beforehand.

Cool place, don't get me wrong but definitely overpriced drinks that don't taste good! I've been here 3 times now, and the service is lacking for sure. I would say its a one time/try it out kind of place, but if it were up to me, I would probably get better drinks elsewhere.

Cool Tiki bar that serves flamingh drinks. It was fun, i hate to give this place a bad review because it just was not my cup of tea- or flaming tropical drink. if you like tacky bars check it out- if you are looking for good craft beers and cocktails try the Hubbard Inn
Love this place try the chicken appetizer and short ribs!!!! Super cool and low key. Definitely would recommend this

Love the drinks here ! They are pretty strong! But what a fun indoor space! Especially appreciate the whole tiki bar vibe in the winters! Takes your mind away from the cold for a while!
I also like the customer service here. Even though there is usually a line, they try to keep it moving and almost ever ytime the guy at the door will apologize for the wait. Being on hubbard amongst other bars which have some jerks at the door, this is really refreshing! Gone back several times, and will keep going !

Great tiki bar!  From the moment that you arrive in the alley and walk in, you know that this place is special.  The cocktails were simply  amazing.  My only complaint was that it was very crowded and it took 10-15 minutes to get a cocktail.  This was largely due to the fact that there were not enough bartenders for the crowd. The precision that each drink is made with is amazing.  Our bartender was making 4 different drinks at a time and she knew every ingredient by heart.  It was quite impressive.  I would definitely return here...

Atmosphere is great-- classy, tiki bar feel. Love the decor, the lighting is on point and it really feels kind of like a secret spot. Drink presentation is also really great. The drinks are elaborate and honestly very beautiful... but am I the only one that didn't think they tasted good? I went with a large group of 9 and we all got different drinks and they honestly all kind of tasted like paint... maybe I just have a weird palette. Very expensive, but cool spot. Would probably come again (once I have some more money to spend).

To say that Paul McGee would make even Don The Beachcomber proud would be an understatement. Three Dots epitomizes the classic tiki bar concept and in some ways even reinvents it.

The bar's name is equally as cryptic as it entrance, which is hidden in an alley off of a busy street in river north. Although I've heard lines can be long on Fridays, we encountered no such thing at 6:00 pm on a Monday.

Lucky for us we had seats at the bar all to ourselves, and although it was quite busy, the bartender was more than happy to provide us with guidance as we navigated the extensive Hawaiian and Polynesian inspired cocktail menu.

I was blown away by the Mai Tai. By all accounts it exceeded the drink's Tahesian meaning (good). Accustomed to, and even put off by inferior and frankly awful immatations over the years, I was reluctant to try it, but our bartender convinced me otherwise, and I'm glad she dad. The drink was superb, not even a touch of sweetness and blended beatifully with the rum. It was the strongest drink I had all night and I would come back just to enjoy the Mai Tai again.

The other cocktails we had were also superb. The Rum River Mystic, which appeared to be a take on the Vieux Carre, except with Puerto Rican rum substituted for the brandy. It was dry, bitter and simply outsanding.

We ordered practically the entire food menu and enjoyed the luau chips and pork belly buns. The chips are actually puffed rice reminiscent of pork rinds in appearance and served with a bowl of guacamole. The buns reminded me of the favorite menu item at Takashi, but sadly not nearly as savory and addicting. I thought the chicken curry skewers and Thai fried chicken were rather uninspiring. What food here lacks is spice, plain and simply. Add some chile to the Thai fried chicken and it would pop.

Unfortunately the food here plays second fiddle to the cocktails. And it should. As my friend Onur U puts it, the food is simply there to allow you to drink longer.

Yes, Three Dots and a Dash lives up to the hype. A hidden Tiki Bar with carefully prepared cocktials made with exceptional rum, cryptic polynesian decor, and medicore food....how can you not like this place?

Very cool ambiance and vibe. We got there pretty early so we didn't have to wait for a table.

We came in for happy hour. The drinks were good, but very boozy and also pretty expensive. We ordered a sampler platter for the 6 of us, and that seemed to be enough since none of us were looking for anything too heavy.

Can't be happier with this tiki lounge! I arrived here for a bachelorette party! We had 17 ladies deep and they were able to accommodate us quickly! I called ahead of time and when we arrived we only waited 5 minutes to be seated! Kristin definitely killed it and gots us seated quickly! I am very impressed by their service and the food/ drinks were just great!! Definitely one of the best tiki lounges I have gone to! :)
Don't judge a door by its entry, this is a place to wait in line. Great drinks and great music. A place to bring a group of friends just to relax and have fun. Thanks!

pics.caption: Pieces of eight and a pain killer 109. Great lounge #bar with good #music and awesome #drinks. I'll be coming here again!

review.des:
Three Dots and a Dash is your not-so-typical tiki bar mixed with a speakeasy. First, it's hard to find, so just look for the nearest alley closest to the address! Next, you'll find very sarcastic and well humored door staff - not your standard straight-faced bouncers. Next you walk in to the fantastic tiki decor and are greeted by staff in adorable tiki outfits - I immediately feel like I'm on vacation in Hawaii not in downtown Chicago.

Drinks were all fantastic and our service was great. My favorite drink was the Aku Aku Lapu. Trust me, and try it!

ALOHA! really appreciate the theme here
The location is kinda hidden in the alley, so make sure to ask ppl on the street!
Love their drinks! Must try at least one of their signature cocktails

It took us forever to order one drink, but when it came out, WOW! It was the biggest scorpion-style bowl I had ever seen. I was truly impressed despite being a self-proclaimed tiki bar aficionado. The prices are high, so more of a once-in-a-while kind of place. The atmosphere is more lounge and the menu is more kitsch.

Walking down the stairs to the bar, I wasn't sure what I was going to get. We were treated with a tiki bar circa Honolulu in the 60's. Good music and dim lighting created a great atmosphere. Our bartender, Danny, created creative cocktails that looked even better than the decor.

Bouncer told me to take my hat off when other patrons were wearing hats. Bouncer told my boyfriend to take control of me because he would take my shit of ignoring him when he kept touching me. Super inapproprpriate.

This place was so different and amazing. The drinks are fantastic (and STRONG). We went at 5 p.m. on a Wednesday right as they opened, and the place was nearly fully. I'd recommend calling ahead and making reservations.
We ordered coconut shrimp to snack on, and they were good too.
Great place and good service!

Fun place. The entrance is tucked away in an alley just east of Bub City. (Thanks to the valet guys who didn't assume we were tourists when we asked.)

Sizable menu of tropical drinks.  We came in from 5-degree weather and felt instantly transported to a tiki hut in Polynesia. There are some cozy areas which are great with a date.

Our server was very friendly and funny, even when she leaned in and caught her hair on fire in one of the candles. (That is not the way to warm up, dear.)

Drinks are on the pricey side but they are suitably exotic and truly pack a punch, so I'd say the prices are very fair for what they are.  They don't have a full dinner menu, just a light bites menu. Just so you know, you're coming here to get drunk, not to get dinner.

All in all, this place is fun.  Makes me want to buy a car just to put a dancing hula girl on the dash and a surfboard rack on the roof.

I stumbled across this place on Yelp and decided to check it out. The place is located in an alley and pretty dark setting inside. It's similar to other Tiki Bars I've been to, nice decorations and pretty drinks.

We ordered the Zombie Punch to share between 3-4 people (but could have been finished between 2-3). The bartender recommended this drink as the cool one, as it lights on fire!! We were told the DJ was going on after 10, but we were eager to dance to headed out after we finished our drinks.

A bit pricey, but the drinks are so pretty, it's hard to resist!
We loved our experience at this tucked away Chicago bar, it's like walking into another world. The drinks are fantastic,  and served by excellent bar tenders!
These drinks will knock you on your ass. Good service and very tasty. The bouncer is the best part of the experience--nicest guy we've encountered in Chicago.

it was a miracle of miracles that there was no line on a friday night...say whaaa?!
however once inside that was a different story, it was pretty crowded to say the least however it wasn't terribly long (15minutes?) before we got our first round of drinks.  These cocktails are just plain fun with their "Tiki" names in their fun Tiki cups.
We tried 3Dots and a Dash, Painkiller no 3, Pago pago, Tropical Itch and the Zombie (I'm so easy and fell for the gimmicky dry ice in the skull container...so kewl!). All are rum based as to be expected and all were good and not overly sweet but i can't say any were spectacular or super memorable other than how they were presented.  We also snacked on their Thai Fried chicken which was just ok and coconut shrimp which was decent enough but nothing special.  Does that mean i won't return?  of course i would when I'm in playful tiki mood!
Probably wouldn't come again. Service was terrible. Rude management. Drinks were good and strong.

I had a reservation for a Friday at 5:30. I was very eager to get out and try this place, me and a significant other had a work Christmas party this weekend and were staying in a hotel for the weekend to spend some time out and about. This was our first stop to kick off the weekend. I tried for about 2 weeks trying to get a reservation constantly searching for an open spot to become available.

It started out well, we were impressed by the decor, enjoyed the theme and the ambiance. Our intent was to get a drink and a quick appetizer before heading over to zoo lights. We got to our reservation 30minutes early and they still had a table for us. Someone came and served us water and let us know our waiter would be with us soon. It was all downhill from there...

We waited 15+ minutes with nobody addressing us. Our table was in the middle of the room right near the entryway to the dinning/lounge area. About 3-4 girls were huddled around the computer to the right of the bar near the bigger group area. During our time not one of them came to address us. We saw another group or 2 come in and get seated a few tables over who were promptly greeted by a waiter to take their order.

After about 10 minutes in we had thought about just going to the bar to make our orders (maybe thats what your supposed to do?) but the spots filled up quickly ruling out that possibility. Eventually we decided to call it quits and just walked out without ordering. Rather than waste anymore of our free time waiting for a waiter that may never come, we decided to just get a head start on all the other activities planned for our weekend.

Won't be going back and was a bit disappointed that after trying so hard to get a reservation in that the service was so poor.

Of course I love this place. I love tiki drinks and these are so, so good. The cocktails are very well crafted and beautiful. The atmosphere is an upscale nod to the classic, divey, tiki bars. I love the dark, mysterious vibe. Following the blue light to a side door through an alley is a genius idea and definitely adds to the underground (literally) bar vibe.

I'm not crazy about the food. It's just okay. I'm also not a fan of the location. I'd rather have a great place like this be in a neighborhood and not downtown. But, it makes sense for a Lettuce Entertain You restaurant. I sincerely hope they don't replicate Three Dots in other cities and cheapen it with mass production.

Mocktail Report: While it may seem like a boozefest Three Dots and a Dash has a few options on their menu that can be made non-alcoholically. You still get the tropical flavors and beautiful presentation, but without the other stuff! Just ask your server which ones.

(Tip - make a reservation before you go!)

I absolutely love this place! The atmosphere is like a themed tiki lounge which I was not expecting. Me and a friend were advised to go here because of the drinks. We arrived a little early for lunch so we waited by the bar for our table. Reservations are a must! The bartender was super friendly and very knowledgeable. The drinks were a little strong but in a good way. They were filled with flavor and I had to say i was very impressed (you get your money's worth).The setting is very nice, the music was not too loud so you can hold a conversation. The only thing i didn't like was our waitress once we were seated. She was not very friendly and inattentive. The menu was filled with only appetizers which were great! but we weren't expecting that since we were starving and wanted full meals. Other than that its a great place to have drinks and a good place to take a date.

Before I forget we GPS the location and it took us in circles!! The entrance is through an alley way which was super sketchy. We had to ask for directions.

I'm not even sure what to do about this place.

I suggested a GNO with my friends and thought that this place would be a nice venue to go to since we all haven't been out in RIver North (at night) in a long time.  In theory, this was a great suggestion.  

Fast forward to the night of said GNO when my friend texted me that she was waiting in line (in the alley, mind you.) and to hurry the eff up because she was almost to the front of the line.  I can't even wait in lines anymore, people.  Seriously - I can't even.

Bless my friend for waiting in the line because when I got there, she was already at the front of the line.  When we got inside, we decided to forego the hour wait for the table and just find a place at the bar.  In retrospect, we probably should have just waited for that d*mn table  The bar was packed and it was one of those horrific times where you have to wait  patiently for the bartender to acknowledge you to order a drink.  .Again -  I can't even.

The drinks consist of a large selection of cute, "tropical" drinks. Complete with flowers and fruit.  I got with a whiskey on the rocks ($12 for JACK) and then the Port of Call (simply because it seemed like the best bang for your buck).  

Meh.

Came here for dinner on Friday night and the place was packed but we were able to get a table/booth for our group of 5. I loved the atmosphere of this place - Tiki bar but not too over the top. The food and drinks were good. Surprised that the food was pretty good considering it was a tiki bar. We ordered the Pu Pu Platter and added the tuna crisp and grilled short ribs. My favorite was the pork belly buns, Thai fried chicken, and the short ribs with coconut rice. I ordered the Painkiller No 639 and and three of my friends sharted the Zombie punch. Drinks were good and slow creepers. We did have difficulty finding this place because it was in an alleyway on Hubbard St. The entrance was hidden and the sign is super tiny. The servers wore Hawaiian clothing and were all very friendly and attentive. We had a great time and would definitely recommend this place!

The host was extremely rude and unprofessional. Even though we spent a lot of money.

Bar is great, drinks were great. It's just too bad the host ruined it for us.

Be sure to make reservations for a table even on a weekday.
Their drinks are VERY strong and great. Their food isn't great, don't waste your time on it. Better for a drinking place than anything! Great service!

OMG!!!!! OMG!!!!! I wish I could just take this place home. This place was half speakeasy and half tikki bar.  Drinks are about $15 but the creativity and strength makes them worth every penny. The drinks were as strong as I make my own. Lol

So, so cool.  The drinks are amazing.  The decor is transformative.  The only tiny issue I have is that they spend so much time crafting each drink that the lines and wait can get to be a bit much.  I've been here a couple of times, have one drink and move on because it is so long between drinks.  Alas... the coolness draws me back.

Kurt, the manager totally accommodating for me - I called last minute to make a reservation and they were solidly booked. I told Kurt I had never been there before and it was a special night. The reservation was at 7:30. 9:30 had rolled around and totally forgot to call to tell them we were going to be super late. He STILL accommodated me and my party at that time. And he brought us complimentary drinks as well, which was SO nice. I can't say enough nice things about how nice the staff is here, management, the drinks, etc. I HIGHLY recommend this place, but don't accidentally abuse it like I did - I didn't mean to, but no one should do the same. This review is simply just to say how amazing Kurt is, and his staff. Thanks for turning my Saturday night into a phenomenal and memorable one!!!!

This place is incredibly unique and has a great selection of drinks.  Throw in some really cool drinking glasses, good food, and you've got a recipe for a fun evening.  It's a very popular place so set your expectations appropriately on wait times and availability.  But trust me... it's worth it.

Visiting from Texas and was recommended to try this place out. It was unlike any experience I've ever had! The drinks are not only boozy but beautiful. The atmosphere is inviting, fun, and definitely tiki. It can be a bit of a pain because it gets busy, so def try and make reservations. Regardless of that this place 110% make me love Chicago even more.

Loved this place! SO fun and reminded me of Tahiti! Had a table drink and having the long straws made it a group experience. Our server was attentive yet not pushy. A plus!
We had a reservation as we had 6 people and that was a good idea. Line outside was long.
I will definitely come back here!

Maybe I'm just old but I'd recommend getting early reservations. This place is not worth over an hour wait. Variety of strong drinks, cute presentation and tasty snacks though. Overall, it's a fun tiki bar and it's great for groups. Beware of long lines.

Unrelated, the female servers look adorable in their floral maxi dresses. The male servers look frumpy in their Dad Hawaiian shirts. I get it-it's hard to pull off that kind of style for guys.
Great little place in a basement, with great drinks I prefer my tiki bars to be a little cheesy, run down and look like its from the 90's, but if that's not your thing then this place delivers

Creative drinks, mod-high priced but they take a LOT of time on your drinks (as most Tiki bars seem to do, affixing your glass with the extra decorations etc.). Good, reggae-top 40 type of mixes. They have a DJ and dancefloor as well. There are also tables and could see it being a good candle-lit, intimate-event type of place. But they also had fishbowls of alcohol I saw on tables so guess it could also be a good pregame spot.

It was a bit difficult to find, because the address is not where it says it should be. Where you think it should be, turn right, go around the block and into the first alley way. There should be a bouncer there and its down in a basement. Somewhat of a speakeasy entrance for a non-speakeasy place.

Overall drinks are good, somewhat of a tropical kitschy vibe going on that we expected and could be appreciated more than the many standard bars in the area.
Too expensive, too cheesey and not at all a good representation of the great Chicago Bars.

I never imagined myself falling in love with a Tiki bar located in River North. I really need to stress the never part. But, that is exactly what has happened here and I'm still trying to process how all of this happened. I also just want to let it all happen at the same time.

I had been wanting to come here for a while. A friend had recommended 3 Dots soon after they opened and I kinda blew it off as him just being new to town and falling for everything around him. But, I kept hearing from people I trust that I needed to come here. I knew what I had to do, and come here I did (so much so that I have made sure to return several times over the past few months).

For starters, the bar is a bit hidden. Make sure you go in the alley off of Hubbard and look for the Tiki Poles. You will then walk down and find yourself in a bumping Tiki Bar.

While it's fun being in a place that has a vibe and buzz to it, let's be honest, we're here for the drinks. I don't give a bar 5* unless it really deserves it, and that always comes down to the quality of the drinks. Well, the drinks are good. I mean they are really damn good. In fact, I like to say that they are dangerously delicious. It's hard to pick out just one cocktail, but I do find myself constantly going back to the Dr. Funkhauser. Even still, there is an awesome array of rum based tiki drinks that pack some punch while not tasting like it at all.

Don't be afraid to order some food as well. When I've sampled the food I have been very impressed and happy. The chicken skewers and the crab rangoon have been winners both times I've had them. I won't lie, I also dig the kitsch of it all too.

Basically, if you like cocktails, you need to come to Three Dots and a Dash. You just have to let go and just enjoy it all.
